questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding alpha helix?

choices.text: Stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from the peptide bond.
A complete turn of an alpha helix contains 3.6 amino acyl residues.
Pitch of the helix is 0.54 nm.
Large numbers of charged amino acids disrupt the helix.

questions.solution:
Alpha helix is stabilized primarily by intra-chain hydrogen bonds. 

Alpha helix is the most common and stable secondary structure of protein. It is a rigid, right-handed spiral. A complete turn of the helix contains an average of 3.6 aminoacyl residues. The rise per turn of the helix (pitch) is 0.54nm. 

Large numbers of charged amino acids (glutamate, aspartate, histidine, lysine, and arginine) disrupt the helix by forming ionic bonds or by electrostatically repelling each other.

questions.text: A 23 year old  presented with fever, myalgia, and skin lesion as shown in the image. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows erythema migrans, seen in Lyme disease. It is caused by Borrelia Burgdoferi. 

The lesion has a target center with partial central clearing and a  bright red outer border. It usually begins as a red macule or papule at the site of the tick bite.

The tick implicated is the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, shown in the image below.

Lyme disease has three stages of the disease:

  • Early localized stage is characterized by an erythema migrans(EM) rash, a characteristic "bull's-eye" rash. Patients can also have fatigue, fever, chills, headache, muscle and joint aches, and swollen lymph nodes.
  • Early disseminated stage is characterized by multiple EM Rashes and neurological Symptoms such as facial palsy (Bell’s palsy). Patients can also have cardiac symptoms such as Lyme carditis with features of heart block. There can also be migratory joint pain and swelling, often affecting large joints like the knees.
  • Late features include neurological manifestations including peripheral neuropathy, encephalopathy, and persistent joint pains. 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: In a motor bike accident a young man was thrown off his bike and fell on his left shoulder. O/E there was no fracture but  his left arm was adducted and medially rotated. Which of the following facts regarding the patient is not true?

choices.text: The injury could be at the erbs point, the in between C5 & C6
Loss of flexion at elbow joint
Loss of pronation at the elbow joint
Biceps, Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus and Subclavius are affected.

questions.solution:
The patient's left arm being adducted and medially rotated suggests the characteristic limb position in an injury at the Erb's point, in between C5 and C6. 

  • Nerve to Subclavius( C5, C6) supplies Subclavius 
  • Suprascapular Nerve (C5, C6) supplies Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus
  • Musculocutaneous Nerve (C5, C6, C7) supplies Coracobrachialis, Biceps Brachii, Brachialis (flexors of the arm)

Injury to the Musculocutaneous Nerve will result in weak flexion.

Biceps Brachii is a powerful Supinator of the arm, hence loss of supination occurs with paralysis to Biceps Brachii and not the loss of pronation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided chest pain after a motor vehicle collision. Physical examination revealed bilateral breath sounds and a supine chest radiograph was unremarkable. On performing an ultrasound the following was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above M-mode ultrasound of the right lung shows a stratosphere or barcode sign specific for pneumothorax.

In a lung with pneumothorax, lung sliding is abolished on M-mode ultrasound, and the normal sand-like appearance beneath the pleural line (white line) is replaced by parallel lines, which is termed the stratosphere or barcode sign, suggesting the presence of pneumothorax. 

The image given below shows the stratosphere sign or barcode sign.

Supine chest radiography has low sensitivity for traumatic pneumothorax. Thoracic ultrasound has high sensitivity and specificity for the detection of small or occult pneumothorax in critical care patients.

Other options:

Option B: Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Option C: Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

Option D: A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

choices.text: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.solution:
The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. 

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.

Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.

Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase the risk of digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Digoxin toxicity is not increased by hyperkalemia.

In hyperkalemia, the ATPase alpha subunit is dephosphorylated, which is the binding site of digoxin. This reduces it's binding and effect. Therefore, hyperkalemia does not increase digoxin toxicity.

Factors predisposing digoxin toxicity: 

  • Hypokalemia (more digoxin binds to the Na+/K+ ATPase)
  • Hypercalcemia (increases the risk of arrhythmia)
  • Hypomagnesemia (Mg++ is a co-factor for Na+/K+ ATPase)
  • Renal failure (for digoxin)

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with urethral discharge is treated with the grey kit. This treatment is effective for the control of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, you note reduced muscle stretch reflexes below the knee along with the following findings. This condition is associated with which chromosome?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most commonly associated with chromosome 17.

It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene.

It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest electrophoretic mobility and least lipid content?
questions.solution:
HDL has the highest electrophoretic mobility and the least lipid content. HDL particles are the densest.

On electrophoresis, HDL moves farthest on the electrophoretic plate towards the anode. On the other hand, the chylomicron does not move towards the charged end in electrophoresis, thus having the lowest mobility. As a general rule, lipoproteins with higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with fewer proteins have minimal mobility.

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity.

Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly.

Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence.

Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones are involved.

questions.text: A first-year dermatology resident is called to see a child admitted with the following findings. The parents inform that the child prefers to stay indoors during the day. On investigation, urine porphyrin levels were elevated. Which of the following types is unlikely here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the findings shown- blistering, hypo, and hyperpigmented lesions over the sun-exposed areas (seen in panels A-C), and the absence of similar lesions on non-sun exposed areas (back) are suggestive of porphyria which presents with cutaneous features. Acute intermittent porphyria presents with acute abdominal pain, psychosis with no cutaneous features.

The common porphyrias are: 

  1. Cutaneous disease only:
    • Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
    • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP)
    • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP)
  2. Cutaneous disease and acute attacks:  
    • Hereditary coproporphyria (HC)
    • Variegate porphyria (VP)
  3. Acute attacks only - Acute intermittent porphyria. 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old term primigravida gave birth to a male baby by face to pubis delivery. Which type of pelvis is this mode of delivery commonly seen with?
questions.solution:
Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with anthropoid pelvis.

As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipitoposterior position which leads to a high chance of face-to-pubis delivery.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman's body was retrieved from a manhole. You are suspecting antemortem drowning. Which of the following signs will most likely support your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm is an important sign of antemortem drowning. It manifests as closed hands with firmly grasped weed, grass, sticks, etc. floating in the water. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

The image given below shows a cadaveric spasm of hand, holding grass, as seen in antemortem drowning.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

questions.text: Starter F-75 is started in ________.
questions.solution:
Starter F-75 is started in kwashiorkor.

During the stabilization phase of protein–energy malnutrition (PEM), initiate refeeding with frequent small amounts of F75 (a specially formulated low-lactose milk with 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL to which potassium, magnesium, and micronutrients are added). It will reestablish metabolic control, treat edema, and restore appetite. Give 8–12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day, 100 kcal/kg/ day and 1–1.5 g protein/kg/day. After 3 days, transition to F100 (catch up diet), which provides 100 kcal and 2.9 gm protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, increase to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein 4–6 gm/kg/day.

Beriberi is a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) and requires treatment with thiamine for the resolution of the neurologic and cardiac symptoms.

Scurvy is caused by a prolonged deficiency of vitamin C and is treated with vitamin C supplement therapy.

Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin) and is treated with oral nicotinamide.

questions.text: The M184V mutation in reverse transcriptase results in resistance to all of the following except
questions.solution:
M184V mutation restores zidovudine susceptibility in zidovudine resistant HIV.

M184V mutation causes high level resistance to both lamivudine and emtricitabine (Options A and B).

It also confers low level resistance to abacavir (Option D).

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with shortness of breath. He reports walking slower than his peers due to breathlessness. He has had two hospitalizations for similar complaints this year. His post-bronchodilator PFTs are FEV1/FVC < 0.55 and FEV1 55%.  Under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
This patient belongs to moderate COPD, group E category.

The severity of COPD assessed by the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

 

According to GOLD 2023 guidelines, COPD patients are classified into Group A, B, or E based on the severity of dyspnoea, frequency of exacerbations and hospitilization. Dyspnoea may be assessed using the modified MRC Dyspnoea scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT score)

>=2 moderate exacerbations or >=1 leading to hospitalisation

Group E:
                         LABA+LAMA

consider LABA+LAMA+ICS* if blood eosinophil count >=300

 

0 or 1 moderate exacerbation (not leading to hospital admissions)

Group A: mMRC 0-1, CAT<10

                Bronchodilator

Group B: mMRC >=2, CAT >=10

          LABA + LAMA*

* single inhaler therapy maybe more convenient and effective than multiple inhalers

ICS - inhaled corticosteroids
LAMA - Long-acting Muscarinic Antagonists
LABA - Long-acting Beta Agonists

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

  • 0- Breathless only with strenuous exercise
  • 1- Breathless when hurrying on a level or walking up a hill
  • 2- Walks slower than peers or has to stop for breath when walking on level
  • 3- Stops for breath after walking about 100m or for a few minutes
  • 4- Breathless at rest

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting. The coronary angiography revealed total blockage of the posterior descending artery. While exposing this artery during the procedure, which accompanying vessel is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The middle cardiac vein is present in the posterior interventricular groove accompanying the posterior descending artery, and hence is most likely to be injured in this case. 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with Gorlin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Osteoma is not a part of Gorlin syndrome.

Gorlin syndrome/basal cell naevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the PTCH gene.

Components of Gorlin syndrome include:

  • Basal cell carcinomas
  • Medulloblastoma
  • Bifid ribs
  • Odontogenic keratocysts

questions.text: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is being done in a patient with suspected hemoperitoneum. Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Presence of more than 100,000 RBCs/mm3 is a positive finding
Presence of more than 200 white cells/mm3 is a positive finding
Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy
Amylase levels more than 175 units/dL is a positive finding

questions.solution:
The presence of more than 500 white cells/mm3 in blunt trauma indicates a positive finding of diagnostic peritoneal lavage.

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage detects the presence of intraperitoneal blood. Its use has decreased to virtually nil at many centres with the advent of the FAST examination.

Indications for diagnostic peritoneal lavage are:

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Low abdominal rib fractures
  • Unexplained hypotension
  • Spinal or pelvic fractures
  • Paraplegia or quadriplegia
  • Assessment hampered by altered mental status due to neurologic injury or intoxication.

Procedure:

It is performed through a small infraumbilical incision with the placement of the catheter under direct vision. The supraumbilical approach is indicated in pregnant patients and those with pelvic fractures. Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy.

If no blood is aspirated, a catheter is placed and 1 L of Ringer lactate solution is instilled into the peritoneal cavity and then allowed to drain by gravity. At least 200 mL of lavage fluid should be recovered to allow for accurate interpretation.

Disadvantages:

  • Neither qualitative nor quantitative
  • Cannot identify the source of hemorrhage
  • Relatively small amounts of intraperitoneal bleeding may result in a positive study
  • May not detect small and large injuries to the diaphragm
  • Cannot rule out injury to the bowel or retroperitoneal organs.

Related Pearl: Criteria for evaluation of peritoneal lavage fluid

Positive  Intermediate
  Negative

  • > 100,000 red cells/μL
    > 500 white cells/μL
    = 175 units amylase/dL
  • Bacteria on Gram-stained smear
  • Bile
  • Food particles
  • Pink fluid on free aspiration
  • 50,000–100,000 red cells/μL in blunt trauma
  • 100–500 white cells/μL
  • 75–175 units amylase/dL
  • Clear aspirate
  • < 100 white cells/μL
  • < 75 units amylase/dL

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding zinc supplementation in children with diarrhoea except:

choices.text: It leads to reduced duration, severity, and recurrence of  diarrhea
It reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials
Excessive zinc can cause copper deficiency syndrome
It is given at a dose of 20 mg/day for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Zinc supplementation is usually given for a duration of 10 to 14 days.

  • Age <6 months: 10 mg/day
  • Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Zinc administration for diarrhoea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission.

In addition, it improves diarrhoea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Excessive zinc therapy can lead to copper deficiency syndrome, hence requires the regular monitoring of plasma zinc and copper concentrations.

questions.text: The police authorities rescued a girl from being trafficked for sexual exploitation. She is identified to be a refugee. As a part of the Ujjawala scheme, which of the following benefits will she not receive?
questions.solution:
The girl will not receive remuneration (monetary compensation) under the Ujjawala scheme.

The Ujjawala scheme was launched to combat women and child trafficking in India. The components of the scheme include:

  • Prevention of trafficking by awareness, vigilance, education
  • Rescue of victims from the place of exploitation
  • Rehabilitation of victims
  • Re-integration of victims into their family and society
  • Repatriation of cross-border victims to their place of origin

Some other legislations associated with children in India are:

  • The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009
  • Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000
  • Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (amended in 2006 and 2016)
  • Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO), 2012 under the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR)
  • Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The diagram shown is of the right lung, identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man, known case of diabetes mellitus, presented with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Visual field-testing indicates peripheral vision loss.  The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument during his examination of this patient. What is he measuring by using the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is the Schiotz tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP).

This patient's complaints of headache, eye pain, difficulty in adapting to darkness, and examination findings of peripheral vision loss with increased intraocular pressure, is suggestive of glaucoma.  

Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer. The principle behind its use is that the plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye.

questions.text: What is total communication used for?
questions.solution:
The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of hearing-impaired children.

It requires the incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

questions.text: All the following are true about ESI Act except

choices.text: The state government provides 1/8th of the medical benefit expenses
Medical benefit is given in the form of no cash benefit

questions.solution:
Employee contributes 0.75% of the wage

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
questions.solution:
NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie and cruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania.

The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie's medium.

Other options:

Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig’s medium and NIH polygenic medium are used for the culture of E.histolytica.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune checkpoint inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Durvalumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It is an antagonist of PD-L1 which is a protein-ligand that is present on antigen-presenting cells, T cells, B cells, and some cancer cells.

Immune checkpoint inhibitors inhibit proteins that help the cancer cells evade the immune response. When these proteins are blocked, the brake on the immune system is released and T cells are able to kill cancer cells more efficiently.

Durvalumab is approved for use in metastatic urothelial and Merkel cell cancer. The FDA approved Durvalumab in combination with etoposide and either carboplatin or cisplatin as first-line treatment of patients with extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer.

Other PD-L1 inhibitors include:

  • Atezolizumab
  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones.

These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation.

The below image shows an ammonium urate stone.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which of the following autonomic disorders do not involve the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Syringobulbia is a condition that affects the brainstem, not the spinal cord. It is a neurological disorder characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) which affects the brainstem (medulla).

The following autonomic disorders are associated with spinal cord involvement:

  • Syringomyelia
  • Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
  • Traumatic quadriplegia
  • Subacute combined degeneration
  • Tetanus
  • Stiff-person syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumors

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Rouvière’s sulcus?

choices.text: Minor fissure on the inferior surface of left lobe of Liver
Cystic duct lies inferior to this sulcus
It is a useful landmark in laparoscopic cholecystectomy
The sulcus does not indicate the plane of the CBD

questions.solution:
It is a useful anatomical landmark during hepatic resection and in laparoscopic cholecystectomy - since the cystic duct and artery lie anterosuperior to the sulcus while the common bile duct lies posteroinferiorly.

The fissure of Gans (or Rouvière’s sulcus or incisura hepatis dextra) is a minor fissure on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver behind the gall bladder fossa.

questions.text: The chest radiograph of a young man with sarcoidosis shows pulmonary infiltrates in the upper lobes of his lungs without hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the grade of lung involvement according to Scadding scoring system?
questions.solution:
According to the Scadding scoring system, the presence of pulmonary infiltrates alone represents grade III.

The Scadding scoring system is used to grade lung involvement in sarcoidosis. It is based on the chest radiograph findings:

  • Grade I: Hilar lymphadenopathy, often with right paratracheal involvement. No pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Grade II: Hilar lymphadenopathy + pulmonary infiltrates
  • Grade III: Pulmonary infiltrates only
  • Grade IV: Fibrosis

Sarcoidosis predominantly involves the upper lobes of the lungs.

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: Which of the following is used to assess the depth of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The depth of the gastric carcinoma is assessed by endoluminal ultrasound.

In endoluminal ultrasonography, the transducer is usually attached to the tip of the instrument distally, and five layers of the gastric wall may be identified, helping in assessing the depth of invasion (T component of the staging) of cancer with more than 90% accuracy.

Pre-operative staging is done with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdominal/pelvis. The most important prognostic indicators in gastric cancer are - lymph node involvement and depth of tumor invasion. Endoluminal ultrasound and laparoscopic ultrasound are the most sensitive methods in pre-operative local staging of gastric cancer. 

Other options: 

Option A: Standard abdominal ultrasound can be used to investigate the stomach, but it is less sensitive than other modalities in gastric cancer. 

Option B: Barium meal radiology is now used less frequently due to advances in more sensitive diagnostic tools like endoscopy and CT imaging with oral contrast, replacing contrast radiology in investigating gastric malignancies. However, CT remains less accurate in the T-staging of gastric cancer compared to endoluminal ultrasound. 

Option D: Laparoscopy is routine in the assessment of gastric cancer. However, the main limitation is in the evaluation of posterior extension, where CT and endoluminal ultrasound can provide this information.

questions.text: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?

choices.text: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is starch iodide.

Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the well.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding features of Friedrich’s ataxia, except _______

choices.text: Progressive ataxia is the most common presentation
Extensor plantar with brisk lower limb reflexes are observed

questions.solution:
Friedreich’s ataxia

Symptoms and Signs

  • Friedreich’s ataxia presents before 25 years of age with progressive staggering gait, frequent falling, and titubation.
  • The lower extremities are more severely involved than the upper ones.
  • Dysarthria occasionally is the presenting symptom; rarely, progressive scoliosis, foot deformity, nystagmus, or cardiopathy is the initial sign.
  • The neurologic examination reveals nystagmus, loss of fast saccadic eye movements, truncal titubation, dysarthria, dysmetria, and ataxia of trunk and limb movements.
  • Loss of vibratory and proprioceptive sensation occurs. The median age of death is 35 years.
  • Women have a significantly better prognosis than men.
  • Cardiac involvement occurs in 90% of patients. Cardiomegaly, symmetric hypertrophy, murmurs, and conduction defects are reported.
  • A high incidence of diabetes mellitus is found and is associated with insulin resistance and pancreatic β-cell dysfunction.
  • Musculoskeletal deformities are common and include pes cavus, pes equinovarus, and scoliosis.

Extra edge

  • Extensor plantar responses with normal tone in trunk and extremities
  • Absent deep tendon reflexes
  • Weakness (greater distally than proximally)

questions.text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not a cell mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity. 

In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.

The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.

Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: You would expect to see oil drop cataract in a patient with ________
questions.solution:
Oil droplet cataract is seen in galactosemia.

Characteristic associations are:

  • Diabetes - Snowflake cataract
  • Wilson’s disease - Sunflower cataract
  • Homocystinuria - Bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens

questions.text: Half life of dobutamine is
questions.solution:
Dobutamine has a half life of around 2 minutes and it is a very rapid acting drug.

Clinical correlate

Steady state plasma concentration of dobutamine is achieved within 10 minutes.

questions.text: A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation and postmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation

Other investigations for endometriosis include:

  • Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis.
  • Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.

questions.text: In which of the following states will the host not shed the infectious organism?
questions.solution:
The host does not shed the infectious organism in case of a latent infection. This is defined as a state in which the host does not show signs and symptoms of the disease and does not shed the organism.

It can be seen in conditions like herpes simplex, ancylostomiasis, infections due to slow viruses, Brill-Zinsser disease, etc.

Subclinical infection is a state where the host harbours the infectious agent without developing signs and symptoms but sheds the infectious agent. This state is seen in conditions like hepatitis A, rubella, mumps, etc.

Healthy carriers are those who had subclinical infections and later developed a carrier state without suffering from the overt disease. This state is seen in: (mnemonic: CM - DPT)

  • Cholera
  • Meningitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Polio
  • Typhoid

Convalescent carriers are those which shed the infectious agent during the convalescent phase/recovery phase. Such carriers are seen in diphtheria, typhoid, cholera, pertussis, etc.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-

In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)

Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L

Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 =  12 mmHg

Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.

As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: General anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia in pregnant women with ______
questions.solution:
In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia.

The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.

Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia. However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromise ventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context of this MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign is called?
questions.solution:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea and right lower abdominal pain is Murphy's triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called Rovsing’s sign.

This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.

questions.text: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view.

It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: What is the fixative used in Pap Smear ?
questions.solution:
95% ethyl alcohol is used as a fixative.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test

  • It is a screening test only.
  • A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • Ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test.

Procedure

  • The patient is put in dorsal position & labia parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slide.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

NOTE: Use of ether as a fixative has been discontinued as a part of standard practice from the year 1954. Ref: https://www.karger.com/Article/PDF/457827

The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. Historically ether was used along with alcohol as a fixative for pap smear. For further reading on the development of Pap smear technique refer https://www.karger.com/Article/PDF/457827

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins serves as the cofactor of the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate, i.e., vitamin B6, as its coenzyme.

The process of phosphorolytic cleavage of the 1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield single units of glucose 1-phosphate, is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

questions.text: Which of the following bone lesions is not associated with the doughnut sign during a radiotracer uptake study?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma does not show the doughnut sign during radiotracer uptake as the lesion has only lytic activity. Radiotracer is actively taken up by bone-forming areas.

Doughnut sign occurs because of radiotracer accumulation at the periphery of the lesion where there is a reactionary bone formation, with little activity at its centre. Causes include:

  • Aneurysmal Bone cyst
  • Giant cell tumor
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Telangiectatic osteosarcoma

Shown below is the donut sign seen in a case of aneurysmal bone cyst.

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. 

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction 

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: An elderly man diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung underwent surgical resection. Histopathological examination of the resected hilar lymph nodes revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological image of the lymph node showing abundant black-colored pigment within the macrophages are characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis.

The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes, which causes the blackening of the tissues. The carbon dust may also induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. 

The following images show the accumulation of various types of pigments within cells.

The 4th of May is observed as Coal Miner's day.

questions.text: A microbiologist is doing research about antigenic variations in parasites that occur within the host.  Which of the following parasites will exhibit this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation within the host. 

Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation of its variant surface glycoproteins (VSGs) that coat the surface of the organism. There is a cyclical change in the type of VSG expressed every 7-10 days, which protects the trypanosomes from host antibodies against VSG. The parasites exhibiting antigenic variation include Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, Trypanosome brucei rhodesiense, Plasmodium spp. and Giardia lamblia.

 The following image shows Trypanosoma brucei.

The following image shows Plasmodium spp.

The following image shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What process is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 3 and point 4?

choices.text: Movement of Na+ into the cell

Movement of K+ out of the cell

questions.text: Identify the imaging shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Diffusion Tensor Imaging(DTI), an MRI-based neuroimaging.

It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain. White matter tracts of the brain include association fibres, commissural fibres, projection fibres, and subcortical fibres.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) spectroscopy is a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance used to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. It contains N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), choline, creatine, lipids and lactate.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

questions.text: A newborn on routine head-to-toe examination was found to have ambiguous genitalia. Further investigations confirmed a deficiency of the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. What is the mode of inheritance of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It includes a group of autosomal recessive disorders, each of which involves a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, or both.

The most common form is known to occur due to the deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, resulting from mutations or deletion of CYP21A.

(Children) Type X Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease
(Don’t) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Diabetes insipidus
 
(Care) Color blindness
 
(About) Agammaglobulinemia, Alport syndrome, Ocular albinism
 
(Foolish) Fabry disease
  
(Words) Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  
Other conditions: Menke's disease, Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency

questions.text: 70 CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of which of the following?
questions.solution:
CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of fragile X ataxia. It is also known as fragile X tremor and fragile X-associated primary ovarian failure.

Normally, the FMR1 gene is methylated and silenced, and the number of CGG repeats remains < 55.

However, abnormalities in this gene lead to the accumulation of CGG-containing FMR1 mRNAs, which are toxic to the cell. Depending on the type of mutation, there are 2 distinct syndromes:

  • Fragile X ataxia syndrome (FXTAS): 55-200 repeats (premutation) which causes gain of function
  • Fragile X syndrome (FXs): 200- 4000 repeats (full mutation) leading to loss of function

More than half the individuals with FXTAS develop a progressive neurodegenerative syndrome starting in their 6th decade. It is characterized by intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia and may progress to Parkinsonism.

Option B: Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with deletion of paternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the maternal allele.

Option D: Friedreich ataxia is due to GAA repeat sequences in the noncoding regions.

questions.text: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis using Ranson's criteria, except:
questions.solution:
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.

  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality

questions.text: A destitute patient brought to the casualty is found to have the following organism on his body. Which of the following diseases is not spread by this organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a human body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis. Rocky Mountain spotted fever is not spread by lice.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii transmitted through the bite of a dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles. 

The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline.

questions.text: Niacin test is not positive in ___________.
questions.solution:
Niacin test is positive in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium simiae, and few strains of Mycobacterium cheloneii.

Principle of niacin test: M. tuberculosis lacks the enzyme that converts niacin to niacin ribonucleotide. Due to this, a large amount of niacin accumulates in the culture medium and is detected by addition of 10% cyanogen bromide and 4% aniline in 96% ethanol. Positive reaction: Canary yellow.

M. bovis: Niacin negative.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is thyroxine - decreased blood glucose. Thyroxine is a diabetogenic hormone leading to an increase in blood glucose levels.

Effects Of Hormones On Carbohydrate Metabolism:  

  • Catecholamines: Activation of glycogen phosphorylase and therefore glycogenolysis occurs. Hepatic glucose output is increased, producing hyperglycemia.  
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids from the adrenal cortex elevate blood glucose by stimulating gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glucose utilization by the cells.  
  • Growth Hormone: The effects of growth hormone are partly direct and partly mediated via IGF-I (Insulin-like Growth Factor-I). The growth hormone mobilizes FFA from adipose tissue, thus favoring ketogenesis. It decreases glucose uptake into some tissues (“anti-insulin action”), increases hepatic glucose output, and may decrease tissue binding of insulin.

Note: Infusing catecholamine (Epinephrine) mainly promotes glycogenolysis and it is also associated with enhanced rates of aerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscles during exercise (resulting in adenosine triphosphate production).

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents an enzymatic reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. 

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 (v0 - initial velocity) is plotted versus 1/[S] ([S] - substrate concentration) and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors. The x-intercept represents -1/Km while the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax. 

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at the same -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

Note: An allosteric inhibitor alters the conformation of an enzyme upon binding. Enzymes affected by allosteric inhibitors exhibit a sigmoid, not hyperbolic, relationship between V0 and [S].

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with the following skin lesions that are associated with loss of sensation. What type of leprosy are these lesions suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hypopigmented skin lesion with pseudopodia and satellite lesions, suggestive of borderline tuberculoid (BT) leprosy.

Features of the lesions of BT leprosy: 

  • Macules and plaques of various sizes 
  • Dry, scaly surface
  • Pseudopodia or finger-like extensions
  • Satellite lesions 
  • Anesthetic patches
  • Anhidrosis over the lesion
  • Hair loss 

There is asymmetric nerve involvement.

questions.text: According to Meyer Overton rule, which of the following is related to the potency of an anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Meyer Overton rule relates potency of an anesthetic to the solubility in lipid.

This rule suggests that anesthesia occurs when a sufficient number of inhalational anesthetic molecules dissolve in the lipid cell membrane.

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy

questions.text: Out of a family of 4 members, one of them developed COVID-19 infection. Four days later, 2 other members developed the same. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
Secondary attack rate is calculated by the following:

In this scenario, there is one primary case. The total exposed contacts are the other 3 members of the family. The number of persons developing the disease is 2. 

So, secondary attack rate = 2/3 x 100 = 66%.

Note: The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp and stabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. On investigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of severe worsening eye pain with redness and a B-scan showing T sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space is suggestive of posterior scleritis.

Posterior scleritis is the inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. Ultrasonography in posterior scleritis may show the following:

  • Increased scleral thickness
  • Scleral nodules
  • Separation of tenon capsule from the sclera
  • Disc oedema
  • Choroidal folds
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fluid in the sub-tenon space may give a characteristic "T" sign. The stem of the "T" is formed by the optic nerve and the cross-bar by the fluid-containing gap. 

The image given below shows a B-scan ocular ultrasound of the eye.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with a previously diagnosed renal disorder is brought to your OPD with the following reports for a second opinion. What is the likely diagnosis?

Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli.
Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps.
questions.solution:
The findings mentioned are characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Findings in PSGN:

  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix. Polymorphoneutrophil (PMN) infiltration in the early stages.
  • Immunofluorescence: “Lumpy-bumpy” deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

 The image given below depicts the microscopic picture of PSGN. It shows glomerular hypercellularity due to intracapillary leukocytes. Neutrophilic infiltration is present and is marked with purple hematoxylin stain (black arrows).

Other options:

Idiopathic rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis:

  • Light microscopy: Crescents develop in several forms of glomerulonephritis (are a characteristic response to the deposition of fibrin in Bowman’s space)
  • Electron microscopy: No deposits

Focal segmental glomerulonephritis:

  • Light microscopy: Focal sclerotic lesions
  • Electron microscopy: Foot process fusion

Minimal change disease:

  • Light microscopy: Normal
  • Electron microscopy Effacement of foot process

questions.text: You are conducting a study on chronic kidney disease in a population. Your sample size is 28. What formula for standard deviation will you use here?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the sample size is 28, which is <30. For a small sample, usually less than 30, the formula for standard deviation used is:

It is better to use n-1 in the denominator in the case of a small sample. But in the case of a very large sample subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. In those cases, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: All of the following findings would satisfy the Amsel criteria except:
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs are not included in Amsel’s criteria. Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the alteration of normal vaginal flora. It is not an inflammation. Hence, only a few polymorphs are seen on saline microscopy.

Amsel’s criteria are used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  1. A homogenous vaginal discharge
  2. A vaginal pH of > 4.5
  3. An amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test)
  4. Presence of clue cells

If three out of the above-mentioned four criteria are positive, then a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made.

questions.text: A man came to the casualty with severe pain over his thumb. He gave a history of a fall during a football match. X-ray done is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and radiograph point to a diagnosis of Bennett’s fracture.

Bennett's fracture is an oblique, simple intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

The given image shows Bennett's fracture.

Option B: Rolando’s fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal.

Option C: Boxer's fracture is the fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck.

Option D: Chauffeur fracture is a fracture of the radial styloid process.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

choices.text: Females are affected twice as often as males.
Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
It may be associated with measles.

questions.solution:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type.

Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males.

Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. 

Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: A Brazilian tourist who has travelled to India comes to the dermatology OPD with complaints of lesions on his scalp, face, chest and upper back. The lesions are as shown below. On examination, no oral, mucosal or palmoplantar lesions are found and target lesions are absent. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzank smear. What is the target antigen for IgG and C3 in this condition?
questions.solution:
Desmoglein 1 is the target antigen for IgG and C3 in this condition.

The given clinical scenario with the lesions seen in a Brazilian patient and acantholysis on Tzank smear, without oral or mucosal lesions is highly suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus.

It is a less severe form of pemphigus, a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder. Pemphigus foliaceus is commoner in middle-aged people and is insidious in onset with the presence of scaly lesions involving the scalp, face, chest and upper back. Blistering is less common and more scales and erosions are seen as the intraepidermal split is more superficial.

On direct immunofluorescence, IgG antibodies can be observed against desmoglein 1, which is the target antigen. There is no mucosal involvement. The disease is benign, but chronic. 

It is managed by using steroids, cytotoxic immunosuppressants and rituximab.

Envoplakin, Periplakin and Desmoplakin are the target antigens of IgG in paraneoplastic pemphigus. It affects both children and adults and polymorphous bullae, erosions and target lesions are observed over upper body and palmoplantar regions. Additionally, mucositis is also observed.

questions.text: The pelvic ultrasound of a 35-year-old woman is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pelvic ultrasound in a 35-year-old woman shows the 'T-sign' seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy.

In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac. 

In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a  'twin-peak' sign or the 'lambda sign" as the chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers.

The type of twin pregnancy is best diagnosed by transabdominal ultrasound at 11-14 weeks of gestation as the chorion and amnion are not yet fused. At 11-14 weeks, the intervening membranes are clearly visualized at the site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. If not visualised transabdominally, transvaginal ultrasound is done.

Sonographic assessment is done by observing the following:

  Monochorionicity  Dichorionicity
Placental mass 1 2
Presence of intervening membrane T sign twin peak/ lambda/ delta sign
Thickness of intervening membrane <2mm ≥ 2mm

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: The BCR/ABL oncogene most commonly associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia is __________.
questions.solution:
P210 oncogene is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia.

The product of the Philadelphia chromosome (Ph) translocation, the BCR/ABL oncogene, exists in three principal forms (P190, P210, and P230 BCR/ABL)

questions.text: You observe the following breathing circuit being used to ventilate a brain-dead patient who is being shifted to the OT for organ procurement. Which type of Mapleson circuit does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The given circuit is the Bain's circuit which is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Bain's circuit has

  • Inner inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient
  • Outer expiratory tubing: carries exhaled gases out through APL (adjustable pressure limiting) valve

Bain's circuit is often called a universal circuit as it can be used for adult and pediatric patients, for spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

Mapleson's D vs Bain's circuit

questions.text: You want to prescribe a bactericidal drug to a patient having an infection. Which of the following drugs will you not choose?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline is not a bactericidal drug. Tigecycline belongs to a new class of glycylcyclines which is a congener of tetracycline . It is a protein synthesis inhibitor and generally considered as a bacteriostatic.

Isoniazid, daptomycin and ciprofloxacin are all bactericidal agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the limbic system?
questions.solution:
Medial thalamic nuclei are not part of the limbic system. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is a part of the limbic system.

The limbic system controls emotional behavior and is involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. It consists of both the grey mater and white mater. It is located between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus.

Related Pearl: Components of limbic system

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought with worsening memory for the past 3 years. Recently, she has been unable to carry out her daily chores and frequently gets lost in the neighborhood. There is no history of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. MRI brain shows temporal lobe atrophy. Which of the following deposits is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. Aβ amyloid deposition is seen in this condition.

Aβ constitutes the core of cerebral plaques found in Alzheimer's disease. It also gets deposited in the walls of cerebral blood vessels. The Aβ protein is derived by proteolysis from a much larger transmembrane glycoprotein, called amyloid precursor protein (APP).
