questions.text: Ashwini, the mother of a young baby is concerned after she noticed straw yellow-colored stains in her child's clothing while washing them. She brings the child to you for examination. The child has a mildly elevated temperature and the fluid comes out from the umbilicus, whenever the child strains. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the above case is a urachal fistula. The clinical vigentte suggesting straw -yellow fluid (suggestive of urine) along with secondary infection (mildly elevated temperature) and presence of fluid only on straining are all suggestive of urahcal fistula. 

The urachus is an embryologic canal connecting the dome of the fetal bladder with the allantois, a structure that contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord. In this condition, there is continuous urinary drainage from the umbilicus on straining. It usually presents as a tender, swollen mass secondary to infection. 

Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography or computed tomography (CT).

Definitive management is surgical resection of the tract.

A patent vitellointestinal duct, patent omphalomesenteric duct and bladder diverticulum will cause umbilical discharge even in the absence of straining. The discharge in such a case is composed of the contents of the intestine (curdy white in colour mostly).

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings will be seen in patients with chronic alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Chicken-wire fence pattern of fibrosis is seen in the liver biopsy of patients with alcoholic steatohepatitis. This pattern is due to perisinusoidal fibrosis encircling small clusters of hepatocytes. 

Trichrome staining of liver biopsy specimen showing perisinusoidal fibrosis (stained blue) in characteristic chicken-wire fence pattern is given below.

Note: Other conditions with chicken-wire pattern in histopathology:

  • Chicken wire calcification - chondroblastoma
  • Chicken wire vasculature - oligodendroglioma and myxoid liposarcoma

questions.text: The prototype of the device shown in the image below was originally named after which personality?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the anesthesia workstation.

The prototype of this device is Boyle's machine which was first invented by Edmund Gaskin Boyle in 1917. Boyle’s machine, which is used to provide anaesthesia, has evolved over the years into anesthetic workstations, which are currently in use. 

John Lundy: coined the term balanced anesthesia. 

Carl Koller:  proposed local anesthetic property of cocaine. 

Oliver Wendell: coined the term anesthesia.

 

James Taylor Gwathmey from New York invented the Gwathmey machine in 1912. Later, Geoffrey Marshal developed a machine during the First World War (1914-1918) based on the Gwathmey machine.

Boyle developed his machine from Gwathmey's basic model in 1917 and presented his invention at the Royal Society of Medicine in London in 1918. All the credit had gone to Boyle, although Gwathmey and Marshal had developed their machines before him but presented in late in 1919.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a non functional enzyme?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein lipase is not a non-functional enzyme. It is a functional enzyme.

Functional enzymes have a specific function in the plasma such as coagulation factors, pseudocholinesterases, and lipoprotein lipases.

Nonfunctional enzymes have no specific function in the plasma.

  • They are released from the cells as a result of normal wear and tear. Their level is very low in serum.
  • They serve as biomarkers whose levels in the plasma can assist in the diagnosis and prognosis of diseases affecting specific tissues.
  • Eg: Lactate dehydrogenase, Creatine kinase, alkaline phosphatase, gamma glutamyl transpeptidase.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?

choices.text: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells
Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
Calcifications  are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral

questions.solution:
Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is a low-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly. 

Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which is warm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells.

Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the most common malignancy detected in screening mammograms.

Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) and bilateral.

questions.text: A 6-day old infant is being examined. While checking the reflexes, a brisk Moro's reflex is noted. Which of the following conditions is a likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. 

In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities is shown below

The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex: 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly 

Moro reflex in different stages of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

  • Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk
  • Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete
  • Stage III HIE (severe): Absent

Option A: In kernicterus, there is a deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. Hence, the Moro reflex is absent 

Option C: In stage III HIE, the muscles are flaccid and the infant is comatose. Thus, the Moro reflex is absent. 

Option D: Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, the reflex is absent on the side of injury as the nerve supplying the muscles involved (efferent of the reflex) is affected.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 2 days ago. Which of the following will you prescribe as a single dose contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in interval between coitus and drug intake.

LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is 1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy increases but it is not teratogenic.

Advantages of LNG:

  • No oestrogen and its associated side effects
  • Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients
  • Suitable for lactating woman
  • Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse
  • Single-dose therapy 

Contraindications of LNG:

  • Liver disease
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Migraine
  • Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: Advance directive rights of the mentally ill
Procedure for admission, treatment and discharge of the mentally ill

questions.solution:
Establishing mobile mental health camps for the benefit of mentally ill patients is not included under the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

The provisions of this act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

The act also has clear instructions for the central and state mental health authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.

questions.text: What is the transformer ratio of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The transformer ratio of the middle ear is 22:1

The middle ear has to conduct sound waves from a low impedance tympanic membrane to a high impedance oval window. This is done by matching their impedances. It is called transforming action.

Transformer ratio =Areal ratio × Lever ratio

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of generalized edema. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. The serum albumin level is 2.4 g/dL. He responded within 2 weeks of treatment with prednisone. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children
All children require renal biospy for diagnosis
Majority of children achieve complete remission with steroids

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of minimal change in the disease type of nephrotic syndrome. In this condition, all children do not require renal biopsy for diagnosis.  

Minimal change disease is the most common cause (Option A) of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is more common in males and appears between 2 to 6 years of age. It is known as minimal change because, on renal biopsy, the glomerulus appears normal under light microscopy and shows no deposits in immunofluorescence. However, on electron microscopy, uniform and diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes can be seen.

Clinically, the child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalised edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

Diagnosis can be made by urinalysis, which shows proteinuria ranging from 3+ to 4+ protein on urine dipstick and a spot urine protein/creatinine ratio (PCR) of >2. The urinary protein principally contains albumin; hence, it is known as selective proteinuria (Option B). Serum albumin levels are <2.5 g/dL, and there is an increase in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. 

Most children will respond to corticosteroid (prednisone/prednisolone) treatment and will achieve complete remission (Option D) (urine PCR <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick) within the initial 2-3 weeks of therapy. Failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of steroids is known as steroid resistance. These patients require further evaluation, and only then is renal biopsy required. The usual cause of steroid resistance is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3)

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: MRI of a 54-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis showed tectorial membrane thickening. This structure is derived from which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
Membrana tectoria or tectorial membrane is the cranial continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament. 

The posterior longitudinal ligament is present in the vertebral canal on the posterior surfaces of the vertebral bodies. The posterior longitudinal ligaments stretch from the body of the axis (C2) to the sacrum.

Above the level of axis, the posterior longitudinal ligament continues as membrana tectoria. Membrana tectoria extends from the axis to the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is least likely to be seen in a patient with an intestinal type of gastric cancer?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene
Under expression of transforming growth factor α
Loss of heterozygosity at the bcl-2 gene

questions.solution:
In the intestinal type of gastric cancer, several growth factors may be overexpressed, including transforming growth factor α, the epidermal growth factor, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

Molecular pathologies seen in Intestinal type:

  • Mutation or loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene or in β-catenin
  • Inactivation of p53
  • Loss of heterozygosity at the BCL-2 gene
  • Microsatellite instability

Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type: 

  • Mutation of E- cadherin
  • Inactivation of p53

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about CADASIL?

choices.text: It is characterized by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.
Recurrent strokes and dementia are seen.

questions.solution:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene. 

This leads to the misfolding of the extracellular domain of the NOTCH3 receptor that is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle. It is clinically characterized by recurrent strokes (usually ischemic, less often hemorrhages) and dementia.

Arteries in the CNS and in other tissues such as skin show concentric thickening of the media and adventitia, loss of smooth muscle cells, and the presence of basophilic, periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive deposits. Deposits contain the misfolded NOTCH3 protein. These appear as osmiophilic compact granular material on electron microscopy and are consistently detected in the walls of affected vessels.

questions.text: Which gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity?
questions.solution:
PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the following conditions:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Type 1 diabetes

Because these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).

Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease.

Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of patients with an increased risk of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Low dose aspirin may reduce severity of disease
Calcium supplementation above RDA reduces the incidence
Treatment with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates
Megadoses of vitamin C has no proven benefit

questions.solution:
Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. 

However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia. 

Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirin administration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughout pregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor.

Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates.

There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant was brought to the pediatric OPD for a routine checkup. The child had congenital hypoparathyroidism. CT scan revealed thyroid hypoplasia and absent thymus. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal pouches will most likely cause the given features?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of congenital hypoparathyroidism and thyroid hypoplasia, absent thymus on CT scan is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. The defect is most likely to be present in the development of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding calcium homeostasis?

choices.text: 90% of calcium is filtered from the glomerulus
Calcium is reabsorbed mainly from the late distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) promotes calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules
Calcitonin promotes action of parathyroid hormone

questions.solution:
PTH promotes the reabsorption of calcium from the renal tubules. 

Option A: About 41 percent of the plasma calcium is bound to plasma proteins and is therefore not filtered by the glomerular capillaries. The rest of the calcium is filtered through the glomeruli into the renal tubules. 

Option B: Of the filtered calcium, approximately 90 percent is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, loops of Henle, and early distal tubules. However, when calcium levels are low and PTH levels rise, PTH promotes calcium reabsorption from the later DCT. 

Option D: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration and, in general, has effects opposite to those of PTH.

questions.text: The most common cause of death in Churg strauss syndrome is____
questions.solution: Myocardial involvement is the most frequent cause of death in Churg strauss syndrome and is responsible for 39% of mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: The following EEG is that of a 6-year-old girl who is easily distracted in class and exhibits poor scholastic performance. Seizures are precipitated by hyperventilation. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. This is seen in absence seizures.

Absence seizures are characterized by a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control that lasts only a few seconds. However, there is no post-ictal confusion.

Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and also the seizures.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following is a natural ligand for CXCR4?
questions.solution:
SDF-1 is the natural ligand for CXCR4, which blocks the entry of HIV into the cell. 

The natural chemokine ligands for the major HIV co-receptors can block entry of HIV by binding to CCR5 or CXCR4 and prevent HIV binding. There are different chemokine ligands for CCR5 and CXCR4:  

  • CCR5: CC-chemokines RANTES (CCL5), MIP-1α (CCL3), MIP-1β (CCL4)
  • CXCR4: SDF-1

 

Good to know:

  • Strains of HIV that utilize CCR5 as a co-receptor are referred to as R5 viruses.
  • Strains of HIV that utilize CXCR4 are referred to as X4 viruses.
  • Viral strains that are dual tropic utilize both CCR5 and CXCR4 and are referred to as R5X4 viruses.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in a 5-month-old child with Pierre- Robin syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Coloboma iris is not a feature of Pierre–Robin syndrome.

Features of Pierre–Robin syndrome-

  • Micrognathia accompanied by a high-arched or cleft palate
  • Tongue normal size; the floor of the mouth is foreshortened
  • Retrognathia: retracted mandible
  • Glossoptosis/Retroglossoptosis: tongue appears to fall into the throat (retraction of the tongue)

     

Of the children with Pierre–Robin syndrome, 30–50% have Stickler syndrome. Features include prominent joints, arthritis, hypotonia, hypermobile joints, mitral valve prolapse, hearing loss, and ocular problems (myopia, glaucoma, cataracts, retinal detachment).

Pierre–Robin syndrome as shown in the image below:

questions.text:
During a routine health checkup, the following lab reports were obtained for a young male patient. What will be your next step in the evaluation?

Hb: 17 g/dl

TLC: 5500 /μL

Platelets: 1,69,000 /μL
questions.solution:
This patient has increased Hb and normal WBCs and platelets. The next step is to measure RBC mass to evaluate for polycythemia.

A person has to be evaluated for polycythemia if there is:

  • Increased hemoglobin: >16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women, (or)
  • Increased hematocrit: >49 percent in men or >48 percent in women

This condition is due to either a true increase in the number of RBCs (absolute polycythemia) or an apparent increase due to a decrease in the plasma volume (relative polycythemia). Both of these conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass (amount of total blood volume that is occupied by RBCs).

In patients with absolute polycythemia, erythropoietin (EPO) levels must be measured.

  • Primary polycythemia - low or normal EPO levels
  • Secondary polycythemia - elevated EPO levels

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Bohr effect
questions.solution:
Facilitation of oxygen transport depends on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, explained by the Bohr effect. 

When the metabolic activity of tissues increases, the production of CO2 increases. This CO2 diffuses into the blood and in turn, raises the blood H2CO3 and causes an increase in the H+ concentration and a decrease in pH. This decreases the affinity of Hb for O2, shifting the O2- hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This facilitates the unloading of O2 in the tissues. The effect of Pco2 and pH on O2 hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr Effect.

Conversely, in the lungs, CO2 diffuses from the blood to the alveoli and the H+ concentration decreases and theO2 hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left increasing the affinity of Hb to O2.

Note: 

Double Bohr effect occurring in the placenta: Oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve of fetal blood and maternal blood move in opposite directions.

Mechanism:

  • The fetal blood entering the placenta carries large amounts of carbon dioxide, but most of it diffuse from the fetal blood into the maternal blood.
  • Fetal blood - loss of CO2 - reduced H+ - shift to left - loading of O2 i.e. oxygenation of fetal Hb.
  • Maternal blood - increase in CO2 - increase in H+ - shift to the right - Release of oxygen.

questions.text: What is the following instrument used to measure?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Assmann psychrometer which is used to measure humidity.

They consists of two thermometers each inside a double tube for minimizing radiative heating.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (stage 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: The method shown in the image below is called chasing the dragon. Which drug is taken through this route?
questions.solution:
Chasing the dragon is a method used to take heroin.

In this, users inhale a thick, white pyrolysate that is generated by heating heroin base on aluminum foil using a hand-held flame. This means of administration produces heroin concentrations similar to those observed following IV administration.

Other methods used to take drugs are:

  • Mainlining - Intravenous injection
  • Insufflation - Snorting
  • Skin popping - Subcutaneous injection

questions.text: In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are _______
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are the stomach and intestine.

BRESLAU’S SECOND LIFE TEST: It is based on the air entering the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.

Inference:

  • A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test and suggestive of live birth.
  • False positive – in case of stillbirth, air might enter the stomach when a child tries to free obstruction of air passages.
  • Mucus, saliva and air bubbles in the stomach – breathing has occurred.
  • Only mucus – breathing has not occurred.
  • Blood, meconium, liquor amnii in the stomach – child alive at or shortly before birth.
  • Milk in the stomach – the child was alive for some time after birth.
  • Test is invalid in case of putrefaction.

Other tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test –Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of an unrespired lung is 30 – 40g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70.
    • Respired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35

questions.text: In which DNA repair disorder do 'Tiger Tail' bands appear on hair under polarised light microscopy?
questions.solution:
Trichothiodystrophy (TTD) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulphur‐deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy.

  • It is also characterised by photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay and short stature.
  • Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the Nucleotide Excision Repair mechanism.

Image: 'Tiger-tail' bands

questions.text: A young man with parathyroid hyperplasia and pituitary adenoma is diagnosed with multiple tumors in Passaro's triangle. Which of the following structures are constituents of the triangle?

choices.text: Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, lymph nodes
Superior duodenum, head of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Third part of the duodenum, body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach, lesser curvature of stomach

questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from MEN 1 syndrome. Gastrinoma is the most common functional entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN1. Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, and lymph nodes constitute the anatomical area called gastrinoma triangle, also known as the Passaro's triangle.

The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting:

  • The cystic duct
  • The junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum
  • The junction between the neck and body of the pancreas.

More than 70% of the gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome and most sporadic gastrinomas are located in the first and second part of the duodenum. 

Pancreatic gastrinomas are mainly observed in sporadic diseases and are mostly found in the head of the pancreas.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula.

Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features:

  • Continent and dry at rest
  • Urinary dribbling during micturition
  • Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining the pelvic bone and lower vertebrae of an unknown individual, to determine the sex. Which of the following is regarded as the best source of information for the same?
questions.solution:
The greater sciatic notch, which is a part of the ilium is the ideal feature to determine sex.

The sacrum is the least reliable bone for sex determination.

The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.

Pearson and Bell's criteria for sexing of the femur are:

  • Vertical diameter of the femoral head - most useful criterion
  • Popliteal length
  • Bicondylar width
  • Oblique trochanteric length

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complained of an ongoing vibrating sensation in her genitalia caused by her mother opening and shutting doors. Which of the following terms best describes her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing reflex hallucinations. In this scenario, a sensory stimulus in one modality (auditory) is resulting in a sensory experience in a different modality (vibratory).

Option A: Functional hallucinations are triggered by a stimulus in the same modality, and co-occur with it. E.g., a patient may report that he hears voices criticizing him (auditory hallucination) every time he hears the sound of a rotating fan (auditory stimulus), which stops when the fan is not running.

Option C: Panoramic hallucination is a compound hallucination in which the entire sensory input is replaced by hallucinatory perceptions, thus giving rise to a totally different perceptual reality.

Option D: Pseudohallucination is a false perception heard within one's own mind (inner subjective space) rather than perceived as coming from the outside world (outer objective space), and is recognized as unreal.

Other special types of hallucinations:

  • Hypnogogic hallucination- occurs prior to falling asleep (HypnoGogic: Going to sleep).
  • Hypnopompic hallucination- occurs prior to waking up.
  • Extracampine hallucination- experienced outside the limits of one's sensory field. E.g., a patient in Delhi hearing voices from Chennai.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with pain and swelling of elbow. He had a past history of fracture of radial head which was surgically treated. X-ray done is given below. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of myositis ossificans which is a complication of fracture. Recurrence of this condition can be prevented by indomethacin and radiotherapy. 

Myositis ossificans is defined as ectopic benign pathological bone formation. It is most commonly seen after dislocation of elbow or a blow to brachialis, deltoid or quadriceps. The patient presents with gross restriction of range of movements and should be advised not to massage the site as it promotes ossification.

Treatment involves joint rest in the position of function until the pain subsides, followed by gentle movements. After a few months if the pain and restriction still persist then the bony mass is excised.

The X-ray given below shows myositis ossificans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Two days later, he developed features of respiratory failure. Which of the following types is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him.

Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure.

After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.

Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Low pO2

Normal/ low pCO2

High (pAO2-paO2)

Sepsis

Gastric aspiration

Pneumonia

Near-drowning

Multiple blood transfusions

Pancreatitis
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Low pO2

High pCO2

Normal (pAO2-paO2)

Drug overdose

Brainstem injury

Sleep-disordered breathing

Severe hypothyroidism

Myasthenia gravis

Guillain-Barre syndrome

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

 

pO2- partial pressure of oxygen

pCO2- partial pressure of carbon dioxide

(pAO2-paO2)- alveolar- arterial oxygen gradient

questions.text: What is frustrated phagocytosis?

choices.text: Release of lysosomal contents due to damaged membrane
Engulfment of infectious pathogens and degradation by phagolysosome
Release of lysosomal enzymes when phagocytes cannot engulf targets

questions.solution:
The term frustrated phagocytosis refers to the release of large amounts of lysosomal contents into the external environment due the inability of the phagocytes to engulf.

When immune complexes are deposited on relatively flat immovable surfaces, the phagocytes are unable to surround and ingest them. In this case, the activation signals lead to an uncontrolled release of the lysosomal contents, despite lack of phagocytosis. This is known as frustrated phagocytosis. 

Other processes may lead to the release of lysosomal contents into the external environment:

  • Controlled secretion of granule contents - normal response of activated leukocytes
  • Damage to the phagolysosome membrane by certain phagocytosed substances like urate crystals

questions.text: Counter current blood flow is seen in all except_____
questions.solution:
The eye does not have a countercurrent blood flow system.

Heat and substances, including gases, steroids and peptide hormones, can pass from venous blood, interstitial fluid and lymph to the arterial blood; the process is called local counter-current transfer.

Examples of countercurrent blood flow

  • Heat exchange between the arteries and venae comitantes of the limbs.
  • Vasa recta in the kidneys
  • Testes
  • Small intestine

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in the Indian army. An army recruit presents to you with complaints of pain in the right foot. He joined his training 6 months back. His X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing a fracture of the 2nd metatarsal are suggestive of a March fracture. It is a type of stress fracture.

Stress fractures (or fatigue fractures) occur in a normal bone that is subjected to chronic repetitive stress. This initiates a bone remodeling process. When resorption occurs faster than replacement, the bone becomes liable to fracture. Such fractures are typically seen in athletes, dancers, or military personnel who have a strenuous exercise regimen.

Common sites for stress fractures include:

  • Metatarsals (especially the second, march fracture)
  • Calcaneum 
  • Navicular 
  • Distal shaft of the fibula (runner’s fracture)
  • Tibial shaft 
  • Patella 
  • Femoral neck

MRI is the investigation of choice to diagnose stress fractures. It can visualize lower-grade stress injuries before X-ray changes appear. A bone scan is the investigation of choice when multiple sites have stress fractures. 

Most stress fractures are managed using an elastic bandage and avoidance of painful activity until the lesion heals. Stress fracture of the femoral neck should be managed by internal fixation as a prophylactic measure.

The image below shows a stress fracture:

questions.text: What type of antagonism is shown by drugs A and B in the following dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
The parallel rightward shift of the agonist dose-response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.

Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

In non-competitive antagonism, there will be flattening of the agonist DRC.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia risk is highest with the use of _______
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia risk is highest with abciximab and occurs in around 5% of patients. Thrombocytopenia risk is around 1% for tirofiban and eptifibatide.
  • Thrombocytopenia mechanism:
    • Immune mediated
    • Binding of GpIIb/IIIa receptor antagonists
    • Exposure of neoantigens on platelet surface
    • Antibodies against these neoantigens cause thrombocytopenia

questions.text: A microbiologist studying Vibrio cholera added sulphuric acid to a 24-hour peptone culture of the organism and a reddish-pink color developed. Which of the following is true about the test he performed?

choices.text: It is known as methyl red test
A nitrosoindole compound is formed giving it the red colour
The red colour is obtained due to pigment production by the bacteria
The red colour is obtained due to acid & gas production by Vibrio

questions.solution:
The test described here is the 'cholera red reaction' given by Vibrio cholera. When few drops of concentrated sulphuric acid are added to a 24-hour peptone water culture, a reddish-pink colour develops due to the formation of nitrosoindole. Vibrio cholerae reduce nitrates to nitrites and convert tryptophan to indole. These two properties contribute to the cholera red reaction. 

Other options:

Option A: The methyl red (MR) test is used to detect the production of sufficient acid during the fermentation of glucose by bacteria. It is used to classify Enterobacteriacae.

Option C: Vibrio cholera does not produce any colored pigment.

Option D: Vibrio ferments carbohydrates leading to production of acid but no gas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adenosine receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
• Enprofylline is a substituted derivative of theophylline that does not antagonize adenosine receptors resulting in a favorable side effect profile.
  • Doxofylline is another substituted derivative of theophylline that has minimal adenosine receptor antagonism effect.
  • Aminophylline is an ethylenediamine salt of theophylline that has increased solubility in neutral pH. It retains the adenosine receptor antagonism effect of theophylline (option a).
  • Theophylline has adenosine receptor antagonism action (option b).
  • Doxophylline has adenosine receptor antagonism action but very less when compared to theophylline (option d).

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with fever and breathlessness for a month. Chest radiograph shows patchy infiltration in the lower lobes bilaterally and the lung biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Fever, breathlessness with bilateral lower lobe patchy infiltration and Owl's eye inclusion bodies on lung biopsy suggest a diagnosis of pneumonia caused by cytomegalovirus (CMV).

CMV is a herpesvirus. It causes congenital infection in neonates, heterophile antibody-negative infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome in children and adults, and systemic infections (pneumonia, colitis) in immunocompromised patients. Diagnosis is made by PCR. When cultured, infected cells show owl’s eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

2 – Sphenopalatine artery

3 – Greater palatine artery

4 – Superior labial artery

2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery.

The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch
  • Artery to the pterygoid canal
Cavernous part
Runs in the cavernous sinus
  • Branch to the trigeminal ganglion
  • Meningeal branch
  • Branch to the cavernous sinus
  • Hypophyseal branches
Cerebral part/ Supracavernal part
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater and divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: Veena, an adolescent girl has had recurrent episodes of bleeding from her nose and gums. She also gives a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and repeated blood transfusions. Her bleeding time is deranged and flow cytometry reveals markedly decreased CD41 and CD61 expression. A defect in which of the following is most likely seen in her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia which is characterized by defective platelet aggregation.

Decreased CD41 (GPIIb) and CD61 (GPIIIa) expression are diagnostic of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Bleeding in Glanzmann thrombasthenia is quite severe and is typically mucocutaneous, including epistaxis, gingival, and GI bleeding.

Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann thrombasthenia are severe congenital disorders of platelet function. Patients usually present with petechiae and purpura at birth. The diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometric analysis of the patient’s platelet glycoproteins.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

questions.text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.

MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

World Antimicrobial Awareness Week, Nov 18-24 2022, is a global campaign that is celebrated annually to improve awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance and encourage best practices among the public. The theme for this year is “Preventing Antimicrobial Resistance Together” to encourage the prudent use of antimicrobials and to strengthen preventive measures addressing antimicrobial resistance

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia and chronic diarrhea. His mother states that he has 6-8 foul-smelling stools per day. Physical examination reveals a low-grade fever and scattered rhonchi over both lung fields. Sweat chloride testing is elevated on 2 separate occasions. Which of the following drugs is used as a treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). Ivacaftor is used in the treatment of cystic fibrosis.

Ivacaftor is a potentiator of the chloride channel and overcomes its defect. It activates the CFTR-G551D mutant protein.

Remember: IvaCaFToR (CFTR mutation in CF)

questions.text: You come across a child with growth hormone deficiency during your ward rounds. Which of the following features would you not expect in this child?

choices.text: History of short stature at birth

questions.solution:
Children with growth hormone deficiency usually have normal growth at birth. Growth retardation (decline in growth velocity) becomes apparent around 1 year of age. 

Growth in-utero is dependant on genetic, environmental, nutrition and growth factors. GH levels peak at mid-gestation, increase at birth, and then reduce by 2 weeks of life. At around 6 months of age, GH levels reach pre-pubertal levels and from there on have a major influence on growth. Thus the deficiency becomes apparent after a significant period of GH-dependent growth has occurred. 

Characteristic features of growth hormone deficiency (Pituitary Dwarfism):

  1. Normal growth at birth with growth retardation becoming apparent around 1 year of age
  2. Proportionate short stature
  3. Hypoglycemic seizures in newborn
  4. Small larynx with a high-pitched voice
  5. Small genitalia (micropenis)
  6. Delayed skeletal maturation
  7. Delayed dentition
  8. Delayed puberty (sexual infantilism)
  9. Doll-like facial appearance: small, round facies, frontal prominence, depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose), eyes may bulge, underdeveloped mandible and chin, normal head circumference but craniofacial disproportion due to small facies
  10. Short neck
  11. Normal intelligence.

questions.text: Which of the following is eliminated primarily by kidneys?
questions.solution:
Trospium is the only antimuscarinic agent used in an overactive bladder that is eliminated primarily by kidneys.

  • Over 60% of the absorbed drug is eliminated unchanged by kidneys.
  • Dose adjustments are essential in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Solifenacin and oxybutynin are primarily metabolized by CYP3A4.

questions.text: The jug handle appearance in chest X-ray seen in ____.
questions.solution:
The jug handle appearance is seen in truncus arteriosus due to pulmonary arterial hypertension. 

In the jug handle appearance - the handle of the jug is formed by the dilated right pulmonary artery and body of the jug is formed by the dilated right atrium and ventricle due to volume overload.

The X-ray shows truncus arteriosus. Truncus arteriosus is a cyanotic congenital heart anomaly in which a single trunk supplies both the pulmonary and systemic circulation, instead of a separate aorta and a pulmonary trunk.

questions.text: The image below shows the model of a skeletal muscle fiber. Which of the following structures is affected in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene.

This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

ETEPLIRSEN is the first drug approved by FDA to treat patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). It is specifically indicated for patients who have a confirmed mutation of the dystrophin gene amenable to exon 51 skipping, which affects approximately 13-14% of the patients with DMD.

Note- The FDA has approved Vamorolone, a novel corticosteroid for the treatment of DMD. The drug offers enhanced anti-inflammatory properties and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonism as well. It is potentially a safer and more effective alternative to glucocorticoids.

questions.text: What is the vaginal epithelium derived from?
questions.solution:
The vaginal epithelium is derived from the epithelium of the urogenital sinus.

The epithelium of urogenital sinus is formed by the endoderm. 

Note: Urogenital sinus epithelium stains positive for FOXA1, and Mullerian duct epithelium stains positive for PAX2. In 2017, immunohistochemical testing done on embryos revealed vaginal epithelium showed positive immunostaining for both FOXA1 and PAX2.

questions.text: In a patient presenting to the emergency with a firearm injury, you notice peppering around the wound. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for that effect?
questions.solution:
Burning, partly burnt and unburnt propellant flakes and grains may pepper the surrounding of the wound. This effect is known as tattooing. 

Effects seen in entry wounds:

Burning Burning of skin and singeing of hair from hot gases <30 cm  <15 cm
Soiling From the smoke/soot  <50 cm <15 cm
Tattooing Peppering of the skin with unburnt/partially burnt gunpowder  <1 metres 30-45 cm
Rat nibbling Nibbled appearance of the entry wound  >30 cm to 5 metres Not seen

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage found in the structure marked X in the following radiograph?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the pubic symphysis and the type of cartilage seen is fibrocartilage.

Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components make this tissue extremely tough and resilient. Fibrocartilage is present in the following sites:

  1. Pubic symphysis
  2. Manubriosternal joint
  3. Articular discs of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joints
  4. Anulus fibrosus of intervertebral discs
  5. Menisci of the knee
  6. Acetabular labrum
  7. Glenoid labrum
  8. The lining of bony grooves for tendons

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

questions.text: Creatine is synthesized from all except?
questions.solution:
Creatine is synthesized from glycine, arginine, and methionine.

The 1st, 2nd and 3rd steps take place in kidney, liver, and muscle, respectively.

Creatine phosphate donates a phosphate group to ADP to form ATP to be used during the first few minutes of intense muscular contraction. Creatinine is formed in the muscle by non-enzymatic dehydration of creatine and also from creatine phosphate. It is then excreted in the urine. The amount of creatinine excreted is proportional to the muscle mass.

Clinical correlates:

1. Creatine kinase has 3 isoenzymes, which are elevated in the following diseases:

  • CK-MM: Muscular dystrophy, acute kidney injury, autoimmune myositis, hypothyroidism, malignant hyperthermia, and drug-induced myopathy 
  • CK-BB: Stroke, brain injury, and meningitis
  • CK-MB: Myocardial infarction, and myocarditis

2. Normally, creatinine is rapidly removed from the blood and excreted in the urine. Hence, creatinine clearance is a sensitive indicator of kidney function.

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing chemotherapy, now presents with weight gain, ascites, hepatomegaly and hyperbilirubinemia. You suspect sinusoidal obstruction syndrome. Which drug is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome is most commonly associated with high-dose busulfan. Incidence increases when coadministered with CYP inhibitors.

Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome, previously known as veno-occlusive hepatic disease (VOD), involves primary hepatic sinusoidal injury that progresses to diffuse hepatocyte involvement and panvasculitis. This leads to multi-organ failure, and can be life-threatening.

questions.text: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

choices.text: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.

Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Type of graft Split-thickness graft Full-thickness graft
Composition Epidermis + part of the dermis Epidermis + full dermis
Cosmetic appearance Relatively poor Good (texture and pigmentation are better matched)
Graft take/survival High chance of survival Poor (long healing time and vascularization)
Contraction Lesser primary contraction and more secondary contraction More primary contraction and lesser secondary contraction
Use Can cover large areas of defects For areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis (face) is desired

The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife.

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart.

In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

  • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, then tends to decrease.
  • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with all except _____
questions.solution:
Amnesia is characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome, not Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a specific etiology of delirium which is caused by thiamine deficiency, commonly due to alcohol abuse.  

Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Acute, neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait.
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy is a medical emergency, and thiamine should be initiated immediately, either intravenously or intramuscularly.  

Korsakoff syndrome:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by a pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with potential impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning.
  • Permanent in at least a partial form in about 50 percent of the people affected.    

Korsakoff Syndrome

Thiamine deficiency

  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Anton syndrome(visual anosognosia)

Occipital lobe damage (Usually due to stroke)

  • Cortical blindness
  • Confabulation

Kluver Bucy syndrome 

Bitemporal lesions

  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde Amnesia
  • Visual agnosia
  • Hyperphagia
  • Hyperorality
  • Hypersexuality

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of neuropathy seen in diabetes?

choices.text: Distal Symmetric Sensory and Sensorimotor Polyneuropathy

questions.solution:
Distal symmetric sensory and sensorimotor polyneuropathy (DSPN) is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy and is seen in approximately one-third of patients with DM.

Other neuropathies seen in diabetes mellitus are:

  • The most common mononeuropathies are median neuropathy at the wrist and ulnar neuropathy at the elbow
  • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy is typically seen in combination with DSPN
  • Cranial neuropathy (third nerve palsy is the most common) and diabetic neuropathic cachexia

The Michigan diabetic neuropathy score is a screening tool used to assess diabetic neuropathy.

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: Identify the approach for surgery of the prostate as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
The image shows the transvesical approach, also known as Freyer approach.

In this approach, the bladder is opened and the prostate is enucleated by putting a finger into the urethra, pushing forward towards the pubes to separate the lateral lobes, and then working the finger between the adenoma and the false capsule.

Among the other approaches, TURP is most commonly performed.

questions.text: A woman with regular menstrual cycles is undergoing an ultrasound on the 14th day of her cycle. What will the endometrial thickness be?
questions.solution:
During ovulation, the thickness of the endometrium is around 11 mm.

Phase Endometrial thickness

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
The pterygoid branch is not a branch of the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery. It is a branch of the petrous part.

Angiography reveals the characteristic finding of carotid siphon showing multiple bends and producing an S-shaped shadow. The image given below is a magnetic resonance angiogram showing the segments of internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch

Cavernous part

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: Swimmer’s view radio-graph is useful for evaluating:
questions.solution:
Swimmer’s view can enhance the clarity of radiographs involving the cervicothoracic junction by eliminating overlapping shadows of the deltoid and glenohumeral joint.

Open mouth view is for assessing odontoid process.

questions.text: A mislabeled sample of tissue was sent over to the pathology lab for histopathological examination. On microscopy, a characteristic corpuscle as seen in the image was visualised. Which of the following structures is the sample most likely to be from?
questions.solution:
The sample is most likely to be of the thymus because of the presence of the corpuscle of Hassal as seen in the image above.

These are small rounded structures formed from eosinophilic type VI epithelial reticular cells present in the medulla of the thymus. Each corpuscle has a central core formed by degenerated epithelial cells appearing as pink stained hyaline mass. Around this mass, there is a wall formed by concentrically arranged epithelial cells which stain bright pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: Strychnine toxin acts by blocking the action of glycine at the post-synaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Which of the following has a similar mechanism of action but acts presynaptically?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxin has similar mechanisms of action as strychnine but acts pre-synaptically.

Strychnine prevents the uptake of glycine at inhibitory synapses post-synaptically, while tetanospasmin blocks release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) pre-synaptically. This leads to increased release of acetylcholine, thereby leading to the development of spastic paralysis.

The image below depicts the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding acanthosis.
questions.solution:
Acanthosis is characterized by the increase in the number of cells of the stratum spinosum leading to its increased thickness.

Acanthosis is commonly accompanied by other histological changes such as hypergranulosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis. It is seen in verruca vulgaris, chronic eczema, lupus vulgaris.

Kindly note that this should not be confused with the term acantholysis. Acantholysis refers to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges formed by desmosomes. This can be seen in various pemphigus-related disorders and secondary to bullous impetigo and other infections.  

The image below shows acanthosis. Notice the increased thickness of the Malpighian layer and the elongated rete ridges.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Mooser bodies are seen in Typhus fever, not in multiple myeloma.

Histopathological findings seen in multiple myeloma:

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 
  • Russell bodies - Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig
  • Mott cells/ morula cells - Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig
  • Flame cells - Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections
  • Thesaurocytes - Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Which is the most common type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common histopathologic type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

The risk of developing lymphoma increases if the patient has Felty’s syndrome or high levels of disease activity.

questions.text: You notice your surgery chief informing the anesthesia junior resident to place the forearm of the patient in a supinated position so as to avoid a common peripheral nerve injury. Which nerve injury is he most likely concerned about?
questions.solution:
The surgeon is concerned about injury to the ulnar nerve which can be prevented by positioning the forearm in supination compared to pronation. The ulnar nerve is the most commonly injured peripheral nerve following anesthesia.

Other commonly injured nerves include

  • Peroneal nerve
  • Brachial plexus
  • Common peroneal nerve
  • Sciatic nerves

questions.text: 10-month-old Ishaan was presented to the OPD with a 3-day history of lower respiratory tract symptoms and an expiratory wheeze. Chest X-ray showed mild peribronchial thickening.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition described?

choices.text: The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.
It is more common in children who have not been breastfed.
The mainstay of treatment is antibiotics.
There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchiolitis. The treatment is mainly supportive. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.

It is more common in boys, in those who have not been breastfed, and in those who live in crowded conditions. The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.

Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and antibiotics are not indicated.

There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.text: Who was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development Committee in 1943?
questions.solution:
Sir Joseph William Bhore was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development Committee in 1943. This committee was hence named the Bhore committee.

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes can utilize both NAD+ and NADP+?
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is unusual in that it can use either NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.

NAD+ is used primarily in oxidative deamination (the simultaneous loss of ammonia coupled with the oxidation of the carbon skeleton).

NADPH is used in reductive amination (the simultaneous gain of ammonia coupled with the reduction of the carbon skeleton).

questions.text: Which of the following phases is impaired in patients diagnosed with Whipple's disease?
questions.solution:
In Whipple's disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. 

In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction. These bacteria-laden macrophages also accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, brain.

The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia.

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months.

A child makes a tower of:

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years
