questions.text: Which of the following metabolite(s) of morphine is responsible for excitatory effects of morphine?
questions.solution:
Morphine-3-glucuronide is a metabolite of morphine that has little affinity to opioid receptors but may contribute to excitatory effects of morphine.

Morphine-6-glucuronide has actions similar to morphine and is more potent and may be responsible for much of the actions in chronic morphine administration (option B).

Normorphine is a minor metabolite of morphine (option D).

questions.text: Soret band is seen around the wavelength of _______.
questions.solution:
Soret band is seen around the wavelength of 400nm.

It is a distinguishing feature shared by all porphyrins.

Spectrophotometry can be used to detect porphyrin and its precursors in porphyrias.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with Down's syndrome was found to have an IQ score of 55. Which of the following historical terms can be used to describe his level of intelligence?
questions.solution:
An individual with an IQ of 55 was historically termed as a moron.

Classification of the level of intelligence based on IQ:

Level of intelligence IQ
Idiot 0–24
Imbecile 25–49
Moron 50–69
Borderline 70–79
Low normal 80–89
Normal 90–109
Superior 110–119
Very superior 120–139
Near genius >140

Note: The above classification is according to Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine to answer this particular question. In clinical practice, the terms moron, imbecile and idiot are not used. Instead, the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales-5 (SBS-5) is used. It is described below:

IQ/Index score Range
145-160 Very gifted or highly advanced
130-144 Gifted or very advanced
120-129 Superior
110-119 High average
90-109 Average
80-89 Low average
70-79 Borderline impaired or delayed
55-69 Mildly impaired or delayed
40-54 Moderately impaired or delayed

According to DSM-5:

  • The term 'mental retardation' is no longer used. Instead, Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder) is used. 
  • IQ alone can no longer be used to define a person’s overall ability.
  • Psychological testing should accompany clinical assessment.
  • The focus is on adaptive functioning rather than IQ, with the inclusion of severity levels (mild, moderate, severe, profound). Adaptive functioning refers to how well an individual copes with the common tasks of everyday life in three general domains (i.e., conceptual, social, and practical), and how well an individual meets the standards of personal independence and social responsibility.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-enveloped virus that causes hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A and E are non-enveloped viruses, while Hepatitis B, C, and D are enveloped viruses.

Hepatitis A causes acute gastroenteritis and is one of the causes of diarrhea in travellers. It is transmitted via contaminated water. It has a fecal-oral transmission. Symptoms also include jaundice, malaise and fever.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man who came to the dermatology clinic for acne complaints was incidentally noted to have multiple scars suspected to be from 'skin popping'. He is most likely to be abusing which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, opioid abuse is the most likely cause of the skin popping scars in this patient. Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Drugs like heroin, cocaine, barbiturates can be injected intradermally or subcutaneously with the goal of achieving slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration than with intravenous drug use.

LSD and mescaline (hallucinogens) and cannabis are not taken through injections, but by oral route or through smoking.

The image given below shows circular depressed scars from skin popping.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and a transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which of the following is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome. 

Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are:

  • Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall)
  • Functioning pancreatic tumors :
    • Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours)
    • Insulinoma - 30%
    • Glucagonoma
    • VIPoma (least common)

questions.text: A hypothesis stating that people who continue to smoke are at a higher risk of developing lung carcinoma than those who have quit is to be tested. Which of the following study designs would you choose for this purpose?
questions.solution:
To test the given hypothesis that smokers are at a higher risk of developing lung carcinoma than those who have quit, the study design chosen is a cessation experiment.

The outcomes of termination of a habit or removal of an agent considered to be causally related to a disease can be evaluated in a cessation experiment.

It is a type of RCT and preventive trial. If the outcome is a significant reduction in disease then the association of that habit or agent to the disease is strengthened.

A trial of aetiological agents is an experimental epidemiological study to confirm or refute an aetiological hypothesis.

Clinical trials, for the most part, have been concerned with evaluating therapeutic agents, mainly drugs.

An uncontrolled trial is an example of a non-randomised trial where there is no control group for comparison.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following can be used to assess his cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Tc-HMPAO (technetium-99m hexamethyl propylenamine oxime) SPECT is used for the assessment of cerebral perfusion. In Alzheimer's disease, it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.

Other options:

Option B: In-111 (Indium) DTPA is injected intrathecally to assess CSF flow.

Option C: Tc-99m (Technetium) MIBI is used for parathyroid scintigraphy.

Option D: Tl-201 (Thallium) is used in myocardial perfusion scanning.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding drug-induced lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Renal involvement is rare in drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening.

Types of screening:

  1. Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example- Annual health checkups.
  2. High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative.
  3. Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using a chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in α-granules of platelets?
questions.solution:
Serotonin is present in the dense or delta(δ) granules of the platelets, not alpha(α) granules.

Platelets are disc-shaped, anucleate cell fragments that are released from the megakaryocytes in the bone marrow into the bloodstream. The functions of these platelets depend on their glycoprotein receptors, contractile cytoskeleton, and cytoplasmic granules.

There are two types of cytoplasmic granules present in platelets:

  • Alpha granules
  • Dense or delta granules

α-granules contain:

  • Adhesion molecule P-selectin on their membranes
  • Proteins involved in coagulation like -
    • Fibrinogen
    • Coagulation factor V
    • vWF
  • Protein factors involved in wound healing like -
    • Fibronectin
    • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin-binding chemokine)
    • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
    • Transforming growth factor β (TGF β)

 δ-granules contain:

  • Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
  • Ionized calcium
  • Serotonin
  • Epinephrine

questions.text: A patient suffering from a methamphetamine use disorder has increased activity of the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Methamphetamine is a psychostimulant that increases the activity and expression of tyrosine hydroxylase. This causes an increase in the monoamine neurotransmitters including dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

Catecholamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine) are synthesized from tyrosine in the adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells). Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme that catalyzes the hydroxylation of tyrosine to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

The conversion of tyrosine to epinephrine occurs via four sequential steps:

  1. Ring hydroxylation of tyrosine to DOPA: Tyrosine hydroxylase
  2. Decarboxylation of DOPA to dopamine: DOPA decarboxylase
  3. Side-chain hydroxylation of dopamine to form: Dopamine β-hydroxylase
  4. N-methylation of norepinephrine to form epinephrine: Phenylethanolamine-N-Methyltransferase (PNMT)

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows multicellular, pear-shaped macroconidia, arranged in clusters, seen in genus Epidermophyton.

questions.text: You receive a referral for a patient who reports a feeling of extreme heaviness in the arms or legs. As a result, he has been finding it difficult to move his limbs. In which of the following conditions is this type of paralysis seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of leaden paralysis and it refers to a feeling of extreme heaviness, usually in the arms or legs resulting in the difficulty of moving the limbs. It is seen in atypical depression.

Atypical depression is characterized by:

  1. Low mood
  2. Increased sleep
  3. Increased appetite
  4. Weight gain
  5. Becomes sensitive to any comments
  6. Leaden paralysis

Note: Involutional melancholia is a severe depressive state seen exclusively in people between 40-65 years. It is usually associated with the delusions of persecution and nihilism.

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis was brought to the Emergency. His BP was 90/60 mm of Hg and pulse was 110. A gastro-oesophageal bleed is suspected and the given tube is inserted for tamponade. Identify the tube.
questions.solution:
The given tube is a Minnesota tube.

Minnesota tube has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port.

The Minnesota tube or modified-Sengstaken Blakemore tube has an additional oesophageal aspiration port.

questions.text: Which protein is produced by a regulatory gene?
questions.solution:
A repressor protein is produced by a regulatory gene.

In bacterial operons, a regulatory gene, like the lac I gene, which is present upstream of a set of structural genes, codes for a repressor protein (a transacting factor). The repressor protein binds to the operator site and interferes with the progress of RNA polymerase. This blocks transcription of the structural genes and is an example of negative regulation of gene transcription.

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor approved for familial periodic paralysis
questions.solution:
Dichlorphenamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhbitor is approved for familial periodic paralysis. The mechanism for benefit is still unknown but most probable due to induction of metabolic acidosis. 

Chlorpheiramine is a first generation anti-histaminergic agent (Option A).

Diethylcarbamazine is an antifilarial agent (Option C).

Chloroprocaine is a local anesthetic (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the structure marked in the image?

choices.text: It has a triangular fibrocartilaginous facet on which part of the talar head rests
Transection of the ligament leads to adult acquired flat foot
It is a complex of two ligaments
It maintains the medial longitudinal arch of foot

questions.solution:
In the given image, the structure marked is the spring ligament (plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament). It is a complex of three ligaments, namely:

  • Superomedial calcaneonavicular ligament
  • Medioplantar oblique calcaneonavicular ligament
  • Inferoplantar longitudinal calcaneonavicular ligament

The spring ligament is a thick band connecting the anterior margin of the sustentaculum tali to the plantar surface of the navicular.

It is the stabilizer of medial longitudinal arch and the head of the talus. Disruption of this ligament leads to the collapse of medial longitudinal arch and causes flat foot.

The image given below shows the spring ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following patients can be intubated using succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine can be administered in liver disease.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a rapid onset of action and an ultra-short duration of action. It stimulates cholinergic receptors at the neuromuscular junction and muscarinic autonomic sites. The ultrashort duration of action is because it gets rapidly hydrolyzed by butyrylcholinesterase. A decreased concentration of butyrylcholinesterase will prolong the blockade produced by succinylcholine.

In liver disease, the amount of butyrylcholinesterase will decrease (20% of normal), leading to prolonged neuromuscular blockade, but it is not a major concern in clinical practice.

Succinylcholine chloride is used to facilitate tracheal intubation. It provides skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery or mechanical ventilation.

Succinylcholine is contraindicated in: 

  • Burns patients
  • Muscle dystrophies (like Duchenne muscular dystrophy)
  • Known hypersensitivity
  • Multiple trauma, head injury

Related Pearl: Conditions causing susceptibility to succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia

The conditions that predispose to hyperkalemia following succinylcholine administration are:

  • Burn injury
  • Massive trauma, head and spinal cord injury
  • Severe intra-abdominal infection
  • Encephalitis, tetanus and stroke
  • Neuropathy like Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Severe Parkinson’s disease
  • Prolonged total body immobilization
  • Hemorrhagic shock with metabolic acidosis
  • Myopathies (eg, Duchenne’s dystrophy)

So, the use of succinylcholine is relatively contraindicated in patients having these conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with FGFR3 mutations?
questions.solution:
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene are not described in melanomas.

Fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR3) is a receptor tyrosine kinase.

Defects in the FGFR3 gene have been associated with several conditions:

  • Hypochondroplasia
  • Thanatophoric dwarfism
  • Seborrheic keratosis
  • Acanthosis nigricans
  • Bladder cancer
  • Craniosynostosis
  • Severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans (SADDAN)

questions.text: Which factor forms the basis of co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Protein A forms the basis of the co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus.

Protein A bearing staphylococci are coated with IgG antiserum. Protein A binds to the Fc terminal of IgG, leaving the Fab terminal free to combine with its specific antigen. The corresponding antigen is then added to this mixture which causes agglutination of the bacteria. This is known as the co-agglutination reaction. It is used for streptococcal, gonococcal or hemophilus typing.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the fibrolamellar variant of HCC?

choices.text: Recurrences are seen despite better prognosis
Occur under the age of 35 years
Not commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B infection

questions.solution:
Fibrolamellar variant of HCC is not commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive variant (<5%) of HCC. They occur under the age of 35 years, without any gender predilection or identifiable predisposing conditions. 

It usually presents as a single large, hard 'scirrhous' tumor. The tumor is well-demarcated, encapsulated, and may have a central fibrotic area. Histology shows large polygonal cells embedded in a fibrous stroma forming lamellar structures.

Fibrolamellar HCC has a better prognosis compared to HCC due to high resectability, but recurrences are seen despite this. Lymph node metastasis may be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?

choices.text: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
It cannot be detected by sonography
It is diagnosed usually after delivery
Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.solution:
The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography.

In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes:

Outcome Type
Disappears Vanishing twin
Gets compressed Fetus compressus
Flattened through desiccation Fetus papyraceus

Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin:

  • Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the surviving twin
  • Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses.
  • Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin
  • Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise

Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise.

questions.text: A boy who attends school is sent to the principal's office as he often distracts others by rhythmically rocking back and forth on his seat. His mother worried about his behavior brings him to you. She also gives you a history of seizures. On examination, you notice he has blonde hair, fair skin, microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, and growth retardation. His urine changes its color transiently to blue-green on the addition of 1ml ferric chloride solution. What is the cause of CNS symptoms in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue.

High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barrier causing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine and tryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis. 

Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growth retardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density and osteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages.

Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) that are excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNS damage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition.

Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause is hyperphenylalaninemia.

Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include:

  • Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen
  • Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color 
  • Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated
  • Enzyme studies
  • Genetic mutation studies
  • Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide therapy. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Flutamide acts by competitive inhibition of androgen receptors and is used to treat prostate cancer.

Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen that competes with androgens such as testosterone and dihydrotestosterone for binding to the androgen receptors in the prostate gland. By doing so, it prevents them from stimulating the prostate cancer cells to grow.

In addition to its use in prostate cancer, flutamide has been used to treat hyperandrogenism (excess androgen levels) in women, such as in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and Hirsutism.

Other anti-androgens are:

  • Bicalutamide, apalutamide, and nilutamide
  • Spironolactone  (aldosterone antagonist with antiandrogen activity)
  • Cyproterone acetate (progestin with antiandrogen activity)
  • Cimetidine (H2 blocker with anti-androgen activity)

Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators (SARMs) are a class of androgen receptor ligands that have similar anabolic properties to anabolic steroids, but with reduced androgenic side effects. There are no FDA-approved SARMs at present.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to South America was brought to the hospital with fever, enlarged lymph nodes and multiple skin lesions on his face. Tissue sample from the lesion shows the following findings under microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the characteristic pilot's wheel appearance on culture(image) is suggestive of paracoccidioidomycosis caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It is also called Lutz mycosis/ South American blastomycosis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. On culture, yeast form is seen at 37° C and the mycelial form at 25° C.

Microscopy of tissue sample reveals thick walled, round, yeast cells with numerous buds attached to each other circumferentially giving the classic mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Most infections are asymptomatic and few individuals with acute disease present with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and skin lesions.

The below image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

Treatment:

  • Mild/moderate disease: Itraconazole
  • Severe disease: Amphotericin B for 2-3weeks followed by Itraconazole. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which is the first organ to putrefy?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the first organ to putrefy is the brain.

The order of organ putrefaction (from first to last):

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Stomach, intestine, spleen
  3. Liver and lungs
  4. Brain
  5. Heart
  6. Kidney and the bladder
  7. Prostate and uterus
  8. Skin, muscle, tendons
  9. Bones

questions.text: Which of the following is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor retinaculum?
questions.solution:
Extensor pollicis longus is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor retinaculum. Posterior interosseous nerve and anterior interosseous artery are present in the fourth compartment.

Extensor retinaculum attachments:

  • Medially - Pisiform and triquetral.
  • Laterally - Anterior border of the radius.

questions.text: Purely depolarizing cells in optic pathway are ______
questions.solution: The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely depolarizing potential.

questions.text: What is the pathological basis for the given skin finding?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

 

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

questions.text: Most common thyroid malignancy arising from thyroglossal cyst:
questions.solution:
Most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is Papillary carcinoma.

Approximately 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

However, the most common complication of Thyroglossal cyst is infection.

questions.text:
Match the findings of the given patients (i, ii, iii, iv) with the appropriate category of blindness they fall under.

i. Unable to count fingers at 6m 

ii. Vision 1/60 to the perception of light

iii. Best-corrected visual acuity less than 3/60

iv. No perception of light 

 

A. Absolute blindness

B. Economic blindness 

C. Manifest blindness 

D. Social blindness
questions.solution:
Type of Blindness Description
Social Blindness Presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 (20/400) in the better eye and limitation of the field of vision to be less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation
Economic blindness The inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 6 meters
Manifest blindness Vision 1/60 to just perception of light
Absolute blindness No perception of light
Curable blindness That stage of blindness where the damage is reversible by prompt management, e.g., cataract
Preventable blindness Loss of vision that could have been completely prevented by the institution of effective preventive or prophylactic measures e.g.,  xerophthalmia, trachoma, and glaucoma 
Avoidable blindness The sum total of preventable and curable blindness is often referred to as avoidable blindness.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is diagnosed with cholera. Which of the following drug would you prescribe to his family members to prevent the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera.

It should be given for:

  • Adults - a 3-day period in a twice-daily dose of 500mg
  • Children (4-13 years) - 125mg
  • Children (0-3 years) - 50mg

Alternatively, the long-acting tetracycline (doxycycline) may be used for chemoprophylaxis, if the prevailing strains are not resistant. A single oral dose of doxycycline (300 mg for adults and 6 mg/kg for children under 15 years) has proved to be effective.

Chemoprophylaxis is advised only for household contacts or a closed community in which cholera has occurred.

questions.text: What is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction.

Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electron microscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.

4-12 hr

Dark mottling (occasional)

LM: Early coagulation necrosis, edema, hemorrhage

12-24 hr

Dark mottling

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct center

LM: Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations, brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Hyperemic border, central yellow-tan softening

LM: Begining disintegration of dead myofibres, with dying neutrophils, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border

7-10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft with depressed red-tan margins

LM: Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Red-grey depressed infarct borders

LM: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 wk

Grey-white scar, progressive from the  border towards the core of the infarct

LM: increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 mo

Scarring complete

LM: Dense collagenous scar

EM: Electron microscopy

LM: Light microscopy

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the sexual wellness clinic by his wife. She complains that he acts like a woman during sexual intercourse. On questioning, he admits that though he identifies himself as a male, he is sexually aroused with the fantasies of being a woman. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
A natal male gaining sexual arousal by the fantasy of being a woman is called autogynephilia. They are also attracted to women but these individuals are often aroused at the fantasy of having sex or actually engaging in sex with men who treat them like women.

Option A: Transvestism is described as fantasies and sexual urges to dress in opposite gender cloth­ing as a means of arousal and as an adjunct to masturbation or coitus.

Option B: Transsexualism is a person having a strong desire to assume the physical characteristics and gender role of the opposite sex. It is an outdated term, and is referred to as gender dysphoria (DSM-5).

Option C: Androphilia means sexual attraction to men or masculinism.

questions.text: Which compound is made up of N-acetyl galactosamine + iduronic/glucuronic acid?
questions.solution:
Dermatan sulfate is made up of N-acetyl galactosamine + iduronic/glucuronic acid

  • The structure of dermatan sulfate is similar to that of chondroitin sulfate, except that in place of a D-glucuronic acid in β-1,3 linkage to N-acetyl galactosamine, it contains an L-iduronic acid in an α-1,3 linkage to N-acetyl galactosamine.
  • It is mainly present in the skin, but is also found in other tissues.

questions.text: What should the Aedes aegypti index be to ensure almost zero risk of yellow fever spread?
questions.solution:
There is no risk of spread of yellow fever if the Aedes aegypti index remains below 1%. 

Aedes aegypti Index: It is defined as the percentage of houses and their premises in a limited well-defined area showing actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae.

questions.text: While examining the burns on this patient, you find a lack of sensation and capillary refill at the burnt site. What is the degree of burn?
questions.solution:
The characteristic features of full-thickness burns (third-degree burns) are lack of sensation in the burned skin, lack of capillary refill, and a leathery texture that is unlike normal skin.

Deep dermal and full-thickness burns require excision with skin grafting for the patient to heal the wounds properly.

questions.text: Which class of antiplatelet antibodies are seen in patients with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Antiplatelet antibodies in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) are mainly IgG class.

Autoantibodies most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins are IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can be demonstrated in the plasma and bound to the platelet surface in about 80% of patients.

questions.text: The father of public health is:
questions.solution:
The father of public health is cholera, the disease, not a person.

John Snow studied the epidemiology of cholera in London from 1848 to 1854 and established the role of polluted drinking water in the spread of cholera. He is called the father of modern epidemiology. He also calculated the dose of ether and chloroform as surgical anesthesia.

Note: Tuberculosis is called the barometer of social welfare.

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome - diarrhea predominant. Which neurotransmitter is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Serotonin is associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhoea type (IBS-D).

Abnormal serotonin pathways is one of the causes for symptoms in IBS. The serotonin containing enterochromaffin cells are increased in a subset of IBS-D patients. This provides a rationale for the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with multiple bony swellings in her hands as seen in the image below marked 1. The X-ray of her hands is as shown in the image marked 2. Identify her condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows hemangiomas of the hand. The radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the small bones of hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification suggestive of enchondromatosis. This is suggestive of Maffucci's syndrome.

Maffucci's syndrome is characterised by enchondromatosis with hemangiomas of the overlying soft tissue.

Malignant potential of enchondromas:

  • Maffucci's syndrome has a 100% risk of turning into malignancy
  • Ollier disease has a 30% risk of turning into malignancy
  • Solitary enchondroma has a <2% risk of conversion to chondrosarcoma

The most common tumor affecting small bones of the hand is enchondroma. Ollier disease is characterized by multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas.

Melorheostosis is an uncommon mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosing bone with a characteristic dripping wax appearance a.k.a. flowing candle wax appearance. It is also known as Leri disease, 

Haemangiopericytomas are soft tissue sarcomas of vascular origin, comprised of pericytes.

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the  following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between _______
questions.solution:
Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (Mnemonic TAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure)

It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs, and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant of respiration, called the recoil pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following congener of levetiracetam has a higher affinity to SV2A protein?
questions.solution:
• Brivaracetam is an analog of levetiracetam which has 20 times more affinity to SV2A protein. The clinical significance or superiority of such high binding is not yet proved.
  • Brivaracetam is metabolized by amidases and CYP2C9. May cause drug interactions while levetiracetam is largely free of drug interactions as it is mostly excreted unchanged.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole.  Within a few days, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. This is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen results in the formation of characteristic bite cells or degmacytes or blister cells (as shown in the image).

A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

Drugs that carry the risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD deficiency:
