questions.text: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. 

CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) 

  • Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR).
  • Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.

questions.text: Which of the following works by disrupting the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane. 

Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants. 

The mechnisms of action of other disinfecting agents are:

  1. DNA damage
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • DNA reactive chemicals like acriflavin. 
  2. Protein modification
    • Alcohol
    • Chlorine
    • Iodine
    • Heavy metals (e.g. thiomersal)
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
    • Ethylene oxide
    • Acids and alkalis

questions.text: According to the Denis classification, which of the following is not included in the middle column of the spine?

choices.text: Posterior part of the vertebral body
Posterior part of the vertebral disc

questions.solution:
According to the Denis three-column theory, the posterior part of the pedicles is included in the posterior column of the spine, not in the middle column.

The 3 columns of the spine according to Denis classification are depicted in the image below.

The Denis classification is used to describe spinal injuries and classify them as stable or unstable. As per this system, any injury involving 2 columns or more is classified as unstable. Unstable injuries require surgical fixation.

The current AO/ASIF classification that replaced Denis classification reverts back to the previously prevalent two-column theory. It divides the spine as follows:

  • Anterior column: vertebral body and disc
  • Posterior column: pedicles, laminae, facets and posterior ligamentous complex

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of erythematous papulopustular lesions over the center of her face. There is a background of erythema and telangiectasia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient comes with erythema and papules on facial convexities (central face), a characteristic feature of acne rosacea.

It is triggered by exposure to sunlight, spicy food, alcohol, or emotional disturbances. Patients also develop telangiectasia later. They also have a tendency for developing rapid flushing due to temperature change. Rosacea is more common in women of age 30-50 years.

The innate immune response in rosacea appears to be altered. There is increased Toll‐like receptor 2 (TLR2) activity and increased protease activity. 

Demodex mite proliferation in the pilosebaceous follicles of the face has also been suggested as a possible aetiological factor in cutaneous and ocular inflammation. The pathogenesis of ocular rosacea seems to be closely associated with meibomian gland dysfunction.

The table below shows the 4 subtypes and the corresponding treatment options. The subtypes are not equivalent to the progression of the disease.

Subtype Treatment
Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR)
  • Sun avoidance and protection
  • Topical α‐receptor agonists - brimonidine or oxymetazoline
Papulopustular rosacea (PPR)

Active inflammatory lesions:

  • Topical metronidazole
  • Azelaic acid
  • Ivermectin
  • Sodium sulfacetamide
  • Sulfur

Perilesional erythema:

  • Brimonidine
  • Oxymetazoline
Phymatous rosacea
  • Topical skin‐peeling agent if there are large occluded follicles
  • Electrocautery or laser for telangiectases
Ocular rosacea
  • Daily lid hygiene
  • Oily tear‐substitute lubricating eye drops or aqueous gels 

The image below shows rosacea.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Cicuta maculate (water hemlock) is a convulsant, not a cardiac poison.

The following are considered cardiac poisons:

  • Digitalis purpurea - contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin
  • Nerium odorum (Oleander) - contains oleandroside (oleandrin) and nerioside (nerin) which resemble digitalis in action
  • Cerbera thevetia (yellow oleander) - contains thevetin and thevetoxin, similar to digitalis in action.
  • Cerbera odollam - closely related to cerebra thevetia
  • Aconite - Aconitine is the major component
  • Quinine
  • Nicotine

questions.text: A patient with Prader-Willi syndrome needs to be evaluated for obesity but the scale for measuring height in your clinic is broken. Which of the following indices can you still use in this situation?
questions.solution:
The corpulence index can be used in this scenario as it is independent of height. The formula for corpulence index is actual weight/ desired weight.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: Which of the following is most appropriate about the web of disease causation?

choices.text: It implies that individual factors in the web have equal weightage
It implies that all the chains of causation must be controlled to prevent disease
It is mostly applicable for acute and rare diseases
It suggests ways of interrupting the disease occurrence

questions.solution:
The web of causation for a disease suggests a number of ways to interrupt the disease occurrence/progression.

This model was suggested by MacMahon and Pugh in their book ‘Epidemiologic Principles and Methods’.

Web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited in the study of chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed. Sometimes removal of one significant link is sufficient to control the disease.

In a multifactorial event, individual factors are by no means of equal weightage. The importance of each factor is expressed in terms of relative risk.

questions.text: What is the life span of affected red cells in patients with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution: The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal life span of RBC is 120 days.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with a mass bulging into the vagina, difficult intercourse, and back pain. She has a history of hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, you observe that the vaginal vault is protruding outside the introitus. What is the best management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of vault prolapse. Sacrospinous colpopexy is the gold standard management for vault prolapse. 

Vault prolapse presents with pelvic or back pain, the descent of the vault through the vagina, difficulties in intercourse, and difficulty in walking due to the mass. It is commonly associated with a cystocele or a rectocele. 

It can be prevented by identifying and repairing an enterocele and by attaching the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments to the vault during a hysterectomy. 

Vault prolapse is managed as follows: 

  • If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacral suspension
  • If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation/colpopexy - the gold standard 
  • Laparoscopic colpopexy
  • If the patient does not want to retain sexual function:
    • Colpocleisis
    • Le Fort's repair 
  • Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele
  • Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele
  • If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried 
  • Posterior intravaginal slingplasty

Note: Kelly's repair and Burch colposuspension are done to manage stress incontinence. 

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: On which aspect of the humeral head is reverse Hill-Sachs lesion seen?
questions.solution:
The reverse Hill-Sachs lesion is seen on the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

It is also known as McLaughlin lesion. it refers to an impaction fracture of the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

It is seen following a posterior dislocation of the humerus. This occurs due to the impact of the glenoid rim on the humeral head.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her past obstetric history was significant for 2 mid-trimester abortions. On USG, cervical length was 20 mm and no bulging membranes were seen.  What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence. It can be managed with prophylactic cervical cerclage done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation.

Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Investigations for cervical incompetence:

  • In interconceptional period - 
    • Passage of number 6 - 8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain
    • Funnel-shaped shadow in premenstrual hysterocervicography
  • During pregnancy -
    • Per speculum examination showing cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
    • USG revealing cervical length <2.5 cm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm

questions.text: A surgeon is dissecting the ischioanal fossa in a patient with anal cancer. Which of the following statements is correct about its boundaries?

choices.text: Posterior boundary is the perineal membrane
Anterior boundary is the sacrotuberous ligament
Lateral boundary is the obturator internus
Medial boundary is the gluteus maximus

questions.solution:
The lateral boundaries of the ischioanal fossa are formed by obturator internus(with its fascia).

The ischioanal fossa is a wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal in the anorectal triangle. It has a pad of fat. The boundaries include:

  • Anterior: Posterior border of perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Gluteus maximus muscle, Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity, Obturator internus
  • Medial: Sphincter ani externus, Pelvic diaphragm (levator ani).

Clinical significance:

Ischioanal fossa provides a relatively bloodless field during resection of anal cancers, therefore it is an important surgical plane.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

choices.text: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.solution:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Post-splenectomy patients
  • Lead poisoning
  • Hemolytic anemias 

Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.

Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.text: You are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture is included in the major criteria for which organism?
questions.solution:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Basal ganglia calcification can be seen on imaging of patients with all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Basal ganglia calcification is not a feature of hemochromatosis. The causes of pathological basal ganglia calcifications are :

  • Endocrinopathies: Hypoparathyroidism (primary or secondary), pseudohypoparathyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism
  • Vasculitis (e.g. SLE)
  • Mitochondrial disorders (e.g. Mitochondrial myopathy)
  • Infections: Brucellosis, TORCH, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), HIV
  • Other inherited disorders: Neuroferritinonpathy, Cockayne syndrome
  • Radiation
  • Chemotherapy
  • Carbon monoxide poisoning
  • Lead poisoning

The following image is a CT brain showing bilateral basal ganglia calcification:

questions.text: A young girl developed a type of psoriasis secondary to an attack of tonsillitis as shown in the image below. Which of the following genes is closely related to the development of this type of psoriasis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of guttate psoriasis. HLA-C:06:02 is almost invariably related to guttate psoriasis.

HLA-C:06:02 is also linked to many cases of plaque psoriasis. Current evidence suggests that polymorphisms in TNFAIP3 may be associated with response to TNF‐α inhibitors, while patients who express the HLA‐C may respond better to ustekinumab than those who test negative. Another genetic association is HLA B-27, that is linked with psoriatic arthritis. 

Guttate psoriasis, which is usually seen in children and young adults, is preceded by Beta hemolytic streptococcal tonsillitis. However, it can also precipitate chronic plaque psoriasis but to a lesser extent. The lesions are from 2 or 3 mm to 1 cm in diameter, round or slightly oval. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs. Lesions usually resolve over about 3 months.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring, termed as Koebner's phenomenon. It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients.

The image below shows Koebner's phenomenon seen in plaque psoriasis.

 

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • Appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

  • Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)
  • Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities
  • Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized and exanthemic variants are described
  • Scalp psoriasis: well demarcated plaques on the retroauricular areas and posterior upper neck
  • Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent
  • Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns
  • Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches and leukonychia are common on the nail plate

  • Signs:

    • Koebner phenomenon: new psoriatic papules at sites of skin trauma
    • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed

Woronoff ring: an area of blanching surrounding resolving psoriatic plaques

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Which of the following gas was responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy?
questions.solution: The gas responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy, which occurred on 3rd December 1984 at the Union Carbide Pesticide Plant, was methyl isocyanate.

questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: What is the earliest manifestation in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Per-rectal bleeding is the earliest and most common symptom of rectal carcinoma.

Other symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  • Mucus drainage
  • Tenesmus
  • Early morning diarrhoea
  • Pain
  • Weight loss.

questions.text: A person died following bee stings. Which of the following enzymes is of diagnostic value at autopsy in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case is of a suspected anaphylactic death in which tryptase is of diagnostic value.

The postmortem diagnosis of anaphylaxis remains difficult due to the lack of specific biomarkers. Mast cell tryptase (MCT) / tryptase is a sensitive measure of mast cell activation, and high levels will be found after severe anaphylactic reactions, especially those causing severe shock.

Diagnostic tests for suspected anaphylactic deaths are serum tryptase and radio-allergosorbent testing (RAST for IgE).

 

Note: Slightly elevated levels of MCT may also be seen in non-anaphylaxis-associated deaths.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient is being evaluated for longstanding anemia. On clinical examination, you notice the given finding. Which of the following metal poisoning is associated with this characteristic finding?
questions.solution:
The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are seen in lead poisoning and mercury poisoning.

These are bluish-grey gingival lead lines that occur with chronic exposure to lead poisoning.

The image given below shows Burtonian lines on the gums.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A patient presented for an antenatal checkup at 25 weeks of gestation. She had bilateral pitting pedal edema and a history of mild headaches. While updating her antenatal card, a weight gain of 13 kgs in the past 2 weeks was noted. USG revealed gross fetal hydrops and a hyperechoic placenta. Which of the following is not true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is also known as Ballantyne syndrome
Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization
It is associated with elevated liver enzymes
It is a not a form of pre-eclampsia

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may be considered a form of severe pre-eclampsia.

Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development of maternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It is characterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous.

The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblastic damage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence, these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as:

  • Edema
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Liver enzyme elevation
  • Headache and visual disturbances.

However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirror syndrome:

  • Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration
  • Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios
  • The fetus always shows signs of hydrops.

The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetal cystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc.

In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severe features of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of the cause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for the remainder of the pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are used to control and reduce lipid peroxidation during which reactive oxygen species (ROS) are formed. Antioxidants thus fall into two classes:

  • Preventive: These reduce the rate of chain initiation of lipid peroxidation.
  • Chain-breaking: These interfere with the chain propagation phase of lipid peroxidation.

Related Pearl: Types of Antioxidants

Preventive Antioxidants

Chain-breaking Antioxidants
  • Catalase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Chelator of metal Ions-Ceruloplasmin & Transferrin
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Urate
  • Vitamin E
  • Polyphenols

questions.text: How frequently does the rhythmic congestion and decongestion of nasal mucosa occur?
questions.solution: Rhythmic cyclical congestion and decongestion of the nasal mucosa is called nasal cycle. It occurs every 2.5-4 hours and is usually characteristic of an individual.

questions.text: Regarding the two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis which of the following is true?

choices.text: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.solution:
The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis:

  • Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types:
    • The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and
    • The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum
  • The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to the follicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supported aromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedione because of the lack of the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A patient with cardiac output 5L/min and body surface area 1.7m2. What will be the cardiac index (L/min/m2)?
questions.solution:
Cardiac index  is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of body surface.

Cardiac Index = Cardiac output / body surface area.

Therefore Cardiac index = 5L/min /1.7m2= 2.94 L

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias. 

Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.

Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.text: Which of the following is an allosteric inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase?
questions.solution: Allosteric inhibitors of the PDH enzyme complex are NADH, acetyl CoA, and ATP.

questions.text: A 25-year-old artist visits an art gallery. A painting of checkered squares appears distorted only to him, as shown below. He decides to go see an ophthalmologist who after initial evaluation, suggests an FFA. The FFA  shows a characteristic smoke stack appearance. Breakdown of which of the following barriers is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a characteristic smoke stack pattern on FFA is suggestive of a diagnosis of central serous retinopathy. In CSR, the outer blood-retinal barrier is disrupted.

CSR is the serous detachment of the neurosensory retina with focal and multifocal areas of leakage at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), mainly affecting the macular area. That is why the patient who is usually a young male presents with macular symptoms such as blurring of central vision, metamorphopsia.

The blood-retina barrier (BRB) is composed of inner and outer barriers. The outer BRB refers to the barrier formed at the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell layer and regulates the movement of solutes and nutrients from the choroid to the sub-retinal space. By contrast, the inner BRB, similar to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is located in the inner retinal microvasculature and comprises the microvascular endothelium, which lines these vessels.

The image given below shows the smoke-stack pattern seen in CSR.

Amsler grid is used in detecting maculopathy.

Uses:

  • Assess macular function
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

The image below shows Amsler's grid.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

questions.text: During rounds in the neurology ward, an 11-year-old child is observed with the following lesion on his back. Which of the following characteristic skin manifestation of tuberous sclerosis is depicted in this picture?
questions.solution:
The lesion seen in the picture depicts a shagreen patch. This is a characteristic skin lesion found in patients with tuberous sclerosis. It consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the image of the question.

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

  • The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.
  • Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.
  • Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients.
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

Image below: Facial angiofibromas (Adenoma sebaceum):

 

Image below: Periungual fibroma:

 

Images: Confetti skin lesions (R) and confetti (L):

 

Images: Ash leaf macule (above) and Ash leaves (below):

 

Images: Shagreen patch (above) and shagreen texture of sting ray skin (below):

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. During the genital examination, the doctor obtained a sample from in and around the vagina. What test needs to be done on this sample to identify the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains.

The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations up to 36 hours after its deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia. 

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding borderline ovarian tumors?

choices.text: Mitotic figures are < 4/10 high power field
Serous type is more common than mucinous type

questions.solution:
Stromal invasion is not seen in borderline ovarian tumors.

Borderline tumors of the ovary (also called tumors of low malignant potential) are a heterogeneous group of lesions defined histologically by atypical epithelial proliferation without stromal invasion.

The clinical progression of these tumors is distinct from ovarian carcinoma, so they are considered a distinct clinical entity.

Features of borderline ovarian tumors:

  • No stromal invasion
  • Mitotic figures <4/10 high power field
  • Survival rate is 90%
  • Usually occurs between 35-55 years of age 
  • Serous type is the most common, followed by mucinous type.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia presents with the following symptoms. Which of them is not a Schneiderian first-rank symptom?
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is not a Schneiderian first-rank symptom of schizophrenia. It is one of the 4A’s of schizophrenia as described by Bleuler.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

1. Hallucination:

  • First-person hallucination (audible thoughts) - auditory hallucinations of the person’s own voice being spoken aloud.
  • Second-person hallucination (voices directly addressing the patient) - auditory hallucinations of 1 or more voices talking directly to the person. They can be persecutory, complimentary, or issue commands (command hallucination)
  • Third-person hallucination (voices speaking about the patient) - auditory hallucinations of 1 or more voices speaking about the person. The voice may deliver a running commentary or the voices maybe be arguing/discussing the person.

2. Thought phenomenon: 

  • Thought withdrawal-  thoughts being actively removed from a person’s mind.
  • Thought insertion- thoughts inserted into a person’s mind by some external agent.
  • Thought broadcasting- the sense that a person’s thoughts are experienced by others - the thoughts are made audible or may be experienced by others through telepathy.

3. Made phenomenon:

  • Made affect- feelings are imposed on that person by an external agent.
  • Made impulses or drives - an impulse for action is imposed on a person by some external agent.
  • Made volitional acts - a person’s actions are controlled by an external agent; the person is a passive participant in the action.

4. Delusional perception- the person attaches an abnormal significance/meaning to a normal perception, which leads to delusional interpretation. The most common delusion in schizophrenia is the delusion of persecution. These persecutory fears of the patient can range from transient doubts to profound convictions that people are plotting to have them tortured or killed.

5. Somatic passivity- tactile or visceral hallucinations that are thought to be imposed on a person's body by some external agent.

These symptoms are not specific to schizophrenia and may also be present in other psychiatric disorders.

questions.text: Glutamate is synthesized mainly in which part of basal ganglia?
questions.solution:
Glutamate is synthesized mainly in the subthalamic nuclei of basal ganglia. 

Connections within the basal ganglia and the respective neurotransmitters:

Connections between Neurotransmitter
Substantia nigra pars compacta to striatum (Nigrostraiatal projection) Dopamine
Striatum to substantia nigra pars reticulata GABA
Striatum to GPe and GPi GABA
GPe to subthalamic nuclei GABA
Subthalamic nuclei to GPe and GPi Glutamate

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated in all cases
Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis

questions.solution:
All patients with Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome should be treated conservatively with elastic compression. A surgical intervention is only indicated for affected large superficial veins provided the underlying deep system is normal and demonstrates only mild-to-moderate reflux.

Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a sporadic nonhereditary mesodermal abnormality that usually affects a single lower limb with deep veins which have hypoplastic or aplastic segments. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Haemangioma presenting as nevus flammeus (port-wine stain)
  • Varicose veins
  • Soft tissue and bone hypertrophy 

Venous stripping, ligation, excision, or sclerotherapy are done in suitable cases. Low molecular weight heparin should be given to all patients undergoing surgical procedures as this syndrome is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of herpetic keratitis?
questions.solution:
Corneal guttata are seen in corneal dystrophy.

Peripheral guttata are seen in old age—Hassall–Henle bodies. Central guttata, on the other hand, are found in Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: Which of the following predisposes a patient to develop type 2 carcinoma endometrium?
questions.solution:
Type 2 carcinoma endometrium is commonly seen in menopausal women with atrophic endometrium.

Histological classification of endometrial cancer:

Type 1 (Endometrioid) Type 2 (Nonendometriod)
Estrogen dependent Estrogen independent
Occurs in Pre- and Peri-menopausal women Occurs in post-menopausal women
Hyperplasia present Hyperplasia absent
Good prognosis Poor prognosis
Associated with PTEN/KRAS mutation Associated with p53 mutation

Note: Type 1 (estrogen-dependent) endometrial CA is the more common type.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being evaluated for sudden onset of hypersecretory glaucoma, diarrhea, and cardiac failure. Further probing reveals that she had been purchasing groceries from a dealer who was recently arrested for food adulteration. What toxin is likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites

questions.text: PDGF acts through which of the following signaling pathways?
questions.solution:
PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) acts through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

All growth factors that foster the multiplication or development of various types of cells act through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which among the following is an oral cavity lesion with a  high-risk of malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Speckled erythroplakia has a high risk of malignant transformation.

Malignancy risk:

High-risk lesions 

Erythroplakia (homogenous/speckled) 

  •  Seen as red velvety lesions
  •  Speckled type is the most  aggressive
  •  The treatment of choice is surgical ablation 

Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia

  • A white patchy lesion that cannot be rubbed off.
  • Speckled leucoplakia has an erythematous base
  • The treatment of choice is excision

Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis

  • White patches that can be rubbed off with a hyperaemic border.
  • Management includes prolonged treatment with topical antifungals or systemic antifungal therapy. If no improvement or if there are any signs of dysplasia, surgical excision is done.

Medium risk lesions

Oral submucous fibrosis

  • Hypersensitive reaction to betel nut product.
  • Other risk factors are - tobacco, chili, vitamin deficiency 
  • Clinical features - trismus, ankyloglossia, soreness, and burning sensation in the mouth.
  • Management includes antioxidants, intralesional triamcinolone, and surgical excision.

Syphilitic glossitis

  • Associated with tertiary syphilis

Low-risk lesions

Oral lichen planus 

  • Reticulate fine lace-like pattern.
  • Management is topical corticosteroids.   

Discoid lupus erythematosus
Discoid keratosis congenita

Speckled erythroplakia:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child complains that she cannot see anything on the whiteboard clearly.  On ophthalmological examination, she is found to have a 2 mm shortening of the axial length of the eyeball. How much eye power will this lead to?
questions.solution:
Shortening of 2mm of the axial length of the eyeball will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.

In axial hypermetropia, 1mm shortening of the anteroposterior diameter of the eye results in 3 dioptres of hypermetropia. Therefore, 2-mm shortening will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.

In curvature hypermetropia, a 1mm increase in radius of curvature results in 6 dioptres of hypermetropia.

questions.text: Which of the following nitrogenous base contain amino group on the 6th carbon?
questions.solution: Adenine has an amino (NH2) group on the 6th carbon.

questions.text: When does the ovary contain the maximum number of oogonia?
questions.solution:
The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million.

Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.

questions.text: You are asked to place a central line for providing parenteral nutrition to a critically ill patient. Which vein is the most suitable?
questions.solution:
The subclavian vein is considered the most suitable vein for parenteral nutrition, as the catheter lies flat on the chest wall, which optimizes nursing care. Moreover, the rate of infection with subclavian venous access is lowest when compared to jugular access and femoral access.

Disadvantages of subclavian vein central venous access:

  • Subclavian vein stenosis
  • Pneumothorax

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media. It is a painless condition.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It occasionally spreads hematogenously, from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes

It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. Patients have severe hearing loss that is out of proportion to symptoms. Although predominantly conductive, sensorineural hearing loss may also occur if the labyrinth is involved.

A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. 

The image below shows the tympanic membrane in tuberculous otitis media: 

Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseous necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Evidence of primary pulmonary tuberculosis may also be seen on chest radiography. 

Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, and osteomyelitis are also seen.

Treatment includes aural toilet, treatment of secondary bacterial infections, and a full course of antitubercular therapy followed by reconstructive surgery.

questions.text:
The given IVP picture is seen in patients with which of the following?

IVP- Intravenous Pyelography
questions.solution:
The given IVP image shows the hand-shake sign which is suggestive of horseshoe kidneys.

The image below shows both kidneys appearing rotated, with the bilateral pelvicalyceal systems oriented end-on. Additionally, the lower poles of both the kidneys are directed medially towards the spine, as depicted in the accompanying image.  

Horseshoe kidney results from the fusion of two functional kidneys located on either side of the midline, typically connected by an isthmus composed of either functional renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue. In most cases, the fusion occurs at lower poles.  

The ascent of the horseshoe kidney is halted by the inferior mesenteric artery, which prevents it from reaching the normal level of T12- L3. Consequently, the kidney remains lower in the abdomen, making it more susceptible to complications such as reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

The following image shows horseshoe kidneys on abdominal CT:

Note: When both upper and lower poles are fused, it is termed a discoid kidney. 

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: What is the most important prognostic factor in patients with colorectal carcinoma?
questions.solution: The most important determinant of prognosis for colorectal carcinoma is the tumour stage and, in particular, lymph node status. The T-stage (depth of invasion) is the single most significant predictor of lymph node spread.

questions.text: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicative of the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguini sign that is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign.

Indications for breast MRI:

  • Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients
  • Evaluation of breast implants
  • Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors.

Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is not expressed in the B-cell receptor complex?
questions.solution:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival.

B-cell receptor complex expresses the following:

  • CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor
  • CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor
  • CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells

Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment. 

The following VCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves:

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition.

It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: In a patient on chlorpromazine, which of the following side effects can be treated with an antimuscarinic agent?
questions.solution:
The oculogyric crisis is an extrapyramidal side effect of first-generation antipsychotic drugs like chlorpromazine that can be treated by antimuscarinic drugs.

Oculogyric crisis refers to the spasm of the extraocular muscles, causing upward and outward deviation of the eyes.

Antimuscarinic drugs used to treat this condition include procyclidine, biperiden and promethazine.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches. MRI shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given axial T1 MRI is suggestive of meningioma. It involves the mid-falx cerebri and is seen as a spontaneously hyperintense and homogeneously enhanced mass in the midline arising from falx.

Meningiomas are extra-axial tumours (lesions that are outside of the brain parenchyma). They are a non-glial neoplasm that originates from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges and are located anywhere that meninges are found.

Meningioma shows female predominance that may be related to the fact that some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors. They are also associated with NF-2 gene mutation.

Typical meningiomas appear as dural-based masses isointense to grey matter on both T1 and T2 weighted imaging and demonstrate vivid contrast enhancement on both MRI and CT. CSF vascular cleft sign indicates that the mass is extra-axial. There is a cleft between the tumour and normal brain parenchyma.

The image below shows the CSF vascular cleft sign:

Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement of the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based. The image is an axial T1W spin-echo MRI of the brain with contrast enhancement showing dural tail (arrow) in meningioma (arrowhead).

questions.text: The first layer of the sole consists of:
questions.solution:
The first layer of the sole consists of abductor hallucis.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.

Muscles of the sole of the foot are:

1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.

 

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: What is the most common type of renal tubular acidosis?
questions.solution:
The most common type of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is the type 4 or hyperkalemic type.

questions.text: While examining a patient in the dermatology OPD, the senior resident elicits the following finding. What condition does this patient likely have?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dermographism, which is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

It is an urticarial reaction in response to pressure or trauma to the skin. It is the most common type of inducible urticaria.

Simple dermographism or factitious urticaria refers to the triple response of local erythema due to: 

  1. Capillary vasodilatation
  2. Edema
  3. Surrounding flare 

The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the wheals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

In <5% of cases, symptomatic dermographism can occur. It is characterized by severe, disproportionate itching that is worse at night. 

Other rare forms of dermographism associated with urticaria are cholinergic dermographism, red dermographism, and delayed dermographism.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker presents with dry persistent cough and progressive dyspnea. You are suspecting small cell carcinoma of lung. Which of the following tumor markers is likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) in which levels of neuron-specific enolase (NSE) are elevated.

NSE is also called gamma enolase or enolase 2 (ENO2) and is encoded by ENO2 gene. It is a phosphopyruvate hydratase that is produced by small-cell lung carcinomas, which are neuroendocrine in origin. Their levels have been implicated as a prognostic factor for patients with small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the types of hair.

choices.text: Melanin is absent in vellus hair
Vellus hair depth extends to the subcutis
The medulla is thicker in terminal hairs

questions.solution:
Vellus hair extends to the dermis and not the subcutis.

Lanugo refers to the fine, soft, unmedullated and usually unpigmented hair of the prenatal period. It is normally shed in utero in the eighth to ninth months of gestation.

Postnatal hair is of two kinds: vellus and terminal.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of a prolactinoma is highly likely when prolactin levels are > 200 μg/L.

The normal range of serum prolactin (PRL) is 5-20 μg/L. Prolactin levels < 100 μg/L can be due to non-functioning pituitary adenomas or non-neoplastic causes of hyperprolactinemia. MRI brain must be done in all patients with hyperprolactinemia.

Prolactinoma are tumors arising from the lactotroph cells of the pituitary gland, they can be classified as microadenoma(<1cm in diameter, usually non invasive ) or macroadenoma(>1cm, locally invasive to adjacent structures). Clinical features include amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea in women, impotence, loss of libido, infertility in men and if tumor extends beyond sella, there can be visual field defects and other mass effects.

Treatment - In asymptomatic patients and those where fertility is not desired, they do not require treatment and can be monitored using regular PRL measurements and MRI. In symptomatic microadenoma cases, oral dopamine agonists (cabergoline and bromocriptine) form the main treatment for hyperprolactinemia and reduction of tumor volume. For macroadenoma, before starting dopamine agonists visual field testing is to be done, and reassess it with MRI changes every 6-12 month intervals until maximum reduction is achieved, in unresponsive cases consider surgery.

questions.text: In a patient with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, cells are found to be positive for which of the following marker?
questions.solution:
Nodular-lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphomas have Reed Sternberg cells(aka L&H CELL) that are BCL-6 positive & CD 20 positive and CD 15 & CD 30 negative.

Note:

  • CD30 is the most sensitive marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.
  • PAX5 is the most specific marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.

questions.text: A concerned wife brought her 43-year-old husband to the clinic after an episode of light-headedness and palpitations. An ECG was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block.

In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coli.

Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension, which of the following is an unlikely finding on a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
A focal area of oligemia or Westermark's sign is seen in pulmonary embolism.

The signs seen on chest radiograph in pulmonary hypertension are:

  • Enlargement of central pulmonary arteries
  • Rapid tapering of vessels known as vascular pruning
  • Right ventricular enlargement

The ECG shows features of RV strain in patients with PH. The pulmonary function tests show a reduction in DLCO in PAH.

questions.text: You are a junior resident conducting research on the efficacy of different methods to monitor the depth of anaesthesia. Which of the following methods will be not be considered for evaluation in your research?
questions.solution:
Capnography is not considered as it cannot be used to monitor the depth of anaesthesia.

Capnography is a quantitative measure of end-tidal carbon dioxide that is used to assess ventilation in the perioperative period and confirm the correct placement of an endotracheal tube.

Monitors used to assess the depth of anaesthesia: 

  1. Electroencephalography (EEG)
  2. Bispectral index (BIS)
  3. Entropy
  4. Evoked responses (EP) - Motor EP, sensory EP (Auditory, visual, brain stem evoked potential)
  5. Patient state index
  6. Narcotrend.

questions.text: Low dose aspirin should be used with caution in a few patients with co-morbidities. True statement among the following is

choices.text: In diabetics because it can cause hyperglycemia
In children with viral disease because of the risk of acute renal failure
In gout because it can increase serum uric acid
In pregnancy, because of high risk of teratogenicity

questions.solution:
Aspirin at lower doses (<2 g/day) causes urate retention and block the effect of uricosuric drugs.

At intermediate doses (2-3 g/day), there is no effect on urate levels.

Only at high doses (>5 g/day), there is uricosuric effect but such large doses have poor tolerability.

Aspirin use is associated with Reye’s syndrome which is a rare form of hepatic encephalopathy seen in children having a viral disease (Option B).

Low dose aspirin use is not associated with hyperglycemia but can cause hypoglycemia in diabetic patients that warrants caution (Option A).

In pregnancy, the use of aspirin is associated with low birth weight and perinatal complications but not with a high risk of teratogenicity (Option D).

questions.text: Of the following compartment and indicator combinations which is true?

choices.text: Total body water-Cannot be measured directly.

questions.solution:
The ECF volume can be estimated using any of several substances that disperse in the plasma and interstitial fluid but do not readily permeate the cell membrane.

Example- radioactive sodium, thiosulfate ion, and inulin.

Hint : Sodium (Na+) can cross blood vessel but not cell wall passively (therefore used to measure ECF volume )

questions.text: The colony morphology of a bacteria on tellurite blood agar shows small, granular, black colonies. Identify the bacteria.
questions.solution:
The given description of small, granular, and black colonies on tellurite blood agar, is indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

  • Tellurite blood agar is a selective medium for the culture of diphtheria bacilli.
  • The diphtheria bacilli reduced tellurite to metallic tellurium, which is incorporated in the colonies, giving them a grey or black color.
  • The growth of diphtheria bacilli may be delayed on the tellurite medium and colonies may take two days to appear.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of dry skin and lesions as shown. The epidermal protein deficient in this patient is present in:
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of ichthyosis vulgaris which is due to the deficiency of filaggrin protein. They are found in the keratohyalin granules of stratum granulosum in the form of profilaggrin (made of filaggrin monomers).

Profilaggrin undergoes proteolytic processing to yield individual filaggrin monomers that bind and aggregate keratin bundles and intermediate filaments between the stratum granulosum and corneum to form the epidermal barrier of the skin.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was admitted with sudden, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. On examination, he was diaphoretic and dyspneic with an irregular pulse. Despite resuscitative measures, he died within an hour of admission. Autopsy revealed the following gross appearance of the interventricular myocardium. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing dead tissue are suggestive of myocardial infarction. It is characterized by coagulative necrosis.

In coagulative necrosis, despite cell death, the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved for a few days. This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of all proteins, including the enzymatic proteins. This prevents the proteolysis of the dead cells. Ultimately, these necrotized cells are removed by phagocytosis and the lysosomal action of the enzymes of the leukocytes.

Examples of coagulative necrosis:

  • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain
  • Dry gangrene

questions.text: The neurotransmitter predominantly involved in obsessive compulsive disorder is ______
questions.solution: The neurotransmitter predominantly involved in OCD is serotonin. A serotonin hypothesis of OCD has been established and patients respond to treatment with serotonin reuptake inhibitors. Other neurotransmitters involved are dopamine, glutamate and GABA.

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.

questions.text: Which disease shows mutation of RUNX2 transcription factor and presents with abnormal clavicles, Wormian bones, and supernumerary teeth?
questions.solution:
RUNX2 gene mutation result in cleidocranial dysplasia.

It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the following:

  • patent fontanelles
  • delayed closure of cranial sutures
  • Wormian bones (extra bones that occur within a cranial suture)
  • dental abnormalities
  • primitive clavicles
  • short height.

Related Pearl: Skeletal Disease with Genetic Defects

Congenital abnormalities, forelimb anomalies

Hypoplastic nails, hypolastic or aplastic patellas, dislocated radial head, progressive nephropathy
