questions.text: You have posted a 43-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding for dilatation and curettage in the minor OT.  Identify the following instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Sim's curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of the uterine tissue.

questions.text: While assisting a direct laryngoscopy procedure being done on a patient, you notice that the vocal cords are in a slightly abducted position. Which intrinsic muscle of the larynx is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of the vocal cords.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: In beta oxidation, 2 carbon units are released as acetyl CoA per cycle.
In alpha oxidation, one carbon is lost in the form of CO2 per cycle.
Alpha oxidation is an energetic process.
Beta oxidation is the major mechanism that occurs in the mitochondria matrix.

questions.solution:
Alpha oxidation is not an energy yielding process.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of _______
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

questions.text: In which of the following are the pores of Kohn located?
questions.solution:
Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall.

They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between adjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. During the gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores.

When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent through these pores.

questions.text: A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal USG. Which of the following features is suggestive of a pseudogestational sac?
questions.solution:
Central location is a feature of the pseudogestational sac seen in ectopic pregnancies.

Pseudogestational sac is a collection of fluid between the endometrial layers, surrounded by a thick decidua. Its presence increases the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.

Differences between pseudogestational sac and true gestational sac:

Feature Pseudogestational sac True gestational sac
Location within the endometrial cavity Central Eccentric
Shape  Usually ovoid Usually round
Fetal and yolk sac poles Absent Present
Double ring sign Absent Seen
Intradecidual sign Absent Seen

questions.text: Which among the following antihistaminic drugs has additional platelet-activating factor antagonistic property?
questions.solution:
Rupatadine is an antihistaminic drug that has additional platelet activating factor antagonistic property and is indicated in allergic rhinitis.

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) is involved in the pathophysiology of allergic rhinitis, asthma, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is diagnostic of acute kidney injury in a patient?

choices.text: Rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days
Rise in creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dl from baseline within 7 days
Rise in creatinine ≥ 0.5 mg/dl from baseline within 48 hours

questions.solution:
A rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days is diagnostic of acute kidney injury (AKI). 

AKI is an abrupt decrease in kidney function within hours to days. According to the KDIGO definition, it is defined as any of the following:

  • Increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours OR
  • Increase in serum creatinine to ≥1.5 times the baseline within 7 days OR
  • Urine volume <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding exenatide?

choices.text: It can be used for the treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Exenatide is not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog that acts as an insulin secretagogue. As the beta cells are already destroyed and do not secrete insulin in type 1 diabetes, there is no role of drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

Option A - Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog and it is synthesized from exendin-4 

Option C - It is a peptide and hence has to be administered subcutaneously 

Option D - It increases insulin secretion, decreases glucagon secretion, delays gastric emptying, and reduces food intake

questions.text: The image shown below is the technique of insertion of?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of laryngeal mask airway.

Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Classic Laryngeal Mask Airway

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and ventilated patients during anesthesia.

LMA has advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for the inexperienced provider and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

 

Note:

Oropharyngeal airway: inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

 

Nasopharyngeal airway: inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Endotracheal tube: inserted infraglottically after visualising the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text:
The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she has Gainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
  1. Acute salpingitis with peritonitis.
  2. Acute salpingitis with no adhesions.
  3. Acute salpingitis with tubo-ovarian complex
  4. Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
  5. Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion
questions.solution:
Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows:

Stage

Condition 

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions 

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge  

Stage III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess 

Stage V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a patient is 5-9 kg. 

Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cluster A personality disorder?
questions.solution:
Narcissistic personality disorder is not a cluster A personality disorder. It belongs to cluster B personality disorders.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with posterior hip dislocation. Which of the following reduction methods is not used for the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Kocher’s maneuver is used for the management of shoulder dislocation. 

Reduction of hip dislocation (closed or open) should ideally be performed within 6 hours to prevent osteonecrosis of the hip joint.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

1. Allis maneuver- traction applied opposite to the direction of deformity

 

2. Stimson maneuver- downward pressure to the flexed knee (patient is prone and at the edge of the table)

 

3. Bigelow maneuver- longitudinal traction with pressure on ASIS to stabilize the pelvis

 

4. East Baltimore lift maneuver- anterior force on the flexed knee (doctor's and assistant's place hands below the flexed knee)

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are primarily sensitive to_____
questions.solution:
The peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid and aortic bodies, are primarily sensitive to decrease in arterial PO2, although high PaCO2 and low pH also stimulates them and enhance their sensitivity to hypoxia.

Carotid body is more sensitive than aortic body.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist evaluating a patient with glaucoma identifies the following finding on slit-lamp examination. What is the finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pattern of the deposition of pigments on the back of the cornea in pigmentary glaucoma. They are called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is an open-angle glaucoma having the following features:

  • Krukenberg spindles
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly, and this accumulation is called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Radial transillumination defect in the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.

Other options:

Option A: Ferry line: Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs of glaucoma surgery

Option B: Fleischer line/ring: Epithelial iron deposits at the base of the cone in keratoconus

Option C: Hudson–Stahli line: Iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between middle and lower third cornea. This finding is mainly age-related.

questions.text: As an intern posted in the OT, you see the anesthesia resident mark out a line on a patient’s back. She tells you that this is Tuffier’s line and is used as a landmark for performing spinal anesthesia. Which vertebral level does this line correspond to?
questions.solution:
Tuffier's (intercristal) line is a line drawn between the highest points of both iliac crests usually crossing either the body of L4 or the L4–L5 interspace.

This is the landmark to identify the spinal level prior to performing a neuraxial block.

Other bony landmarks:

C7 - Vertebra prominence

T7 - Inferior angle of scapula

L1 - Lower rib margin

S2 - Posterior superior iliac spine
